channel.title: Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti
channel.description: Recent content on Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti

item.title: About this weblog
item.description: Edward Vielmetti has been writing the Vacuum weblog since 1999 from Ann Arbor, Michigan. The topics vary widely, with over 2000 entries in the whole collection. As much as possible, the first page has the current focus, but if you dig deep enough you’ll find lots of things that were interesting once and may be interesting again. The current set of systems that are an area of focus - and the places I draw from for inspiration on each - are as follows.

item.title: Mad libs biography
item.description: Some insprirations: Alexandra Franzen, Need to write a bio? Use this. Molly Gordon, How to write an artist’s statement. DJ Bio, Resident Advisor. Tinder Bio Mad Libs, GQ. How to write a thank you note, Leslie Harpold, The Morning News.

item.title: Upgrade to Hugo 0.20
item.description: I’ve upgraded this weblog to Hugo 0.20, which is available by Homebrew on the Mac and with a series of prebuilt binaries for many systems. Hugo in this 0.20 new release promises a lot of new features, including but not limited to support for rendering calendars. I’ll give it a try. One of my goals of Hugo is getting it to run on linux/arm64. It should be easy, since it’s written in Go, and golang ports are absurdly easy.

item.title: Learning Terraform
item.description: Terraform is a provisioning tool from Hashicorp. It manages the process of setting up and tearing down and updating your computing infrastructure. Commands necessary to set up your machines are stored in files, with just enough language features in that configuration description language to accomplish simple automation efforts and to keep secrets out of common config files. Terraform lives in the same computational universe as other packages like Vagrant, Puppet, Chef, Ansible, and Salt.

item.title: Everything depends on the latest version of everything else
item.description: This seems to be the state of the software development world, where you really only have two states of affairs: State one is really old, stable, standardized, “legacy” code, well documented, portable, runs everywhere, easy to port to new systems and architectures. The “curl” library is probably the archetype of this, written in C. State two is really new, unstable, exciting, “modern” code, always changing, designed largely for a 64-bit Intel architecture, and unpredictably hard or easy to port to new systems and architectures.

item.title: Oblique strategies as a service
item.description: In 1975, Brian Eno and Peter Schmidt collaborated on a card deck of strategies for overcoming creative blocks. This was produced in limited and somewhat varying editions, and when it escaped into the computing world at slightly later date, various electronic versions were produced (including one in FORTRAN). Prentiss Riddle noted some of this history in 2004. The ‘oblique’ code is simple; a file with strategies, one per line, and a function to return a random line from that file.

item.title: Templated issue reporting in Github
item.description: A well-managed software project will inevitably have issues come up that need discussion and resolution. These might be out-and-out bugs, but more often than not they are also difficulties that people have getting started running something complex, or issues that arise when building for an environment that is not the same as what the developers have experienced. The best projects I’ve seen have used the ability for Github to provide a template for the issue report.

item.title: DTE power outage is worst in company history due to high winds
item.description: High winds hit southeastern Michigan on Wednesday, March 8 2017. As a result, many DTE customers lost power. Exact numbers are hard to come by, but DTE’s estimate is that about 800,000 customers were affected, making this the worst storm in company history. Even before the peak of the storm, the DTE infrastructure for notifying customers of outage status and gathering incident information from its customers failed. DTE’s web site was down for the better part of Wednesdsay, and when it came back up it only had the bare minimum of information, with no outage restoration times available and no public-facing map detail of outages.

item.title: February 28, 2017 AWS S3 downtime
item.description: Amazon Web Services had downtime yesterday. Their S3 storage service had what was described as elevated error rates in the US-East zone, and as a result failures started in other AWS services in US-East that depended on S3. The failures were reminiscent of the DynamoDB downtime of September 20, 2015, in that seemingly unrelated services share a common failure mode because of unforeseen interdependencies. A distributed system is one in which the failure of a computer you didn’t even know existed can render your own computer unusable.

item.title: Dogfooding
item.description: To “dogfood” comes from the phrase “to eat your own dogfood”, giving the sense that you are not only producing a product but also consuming it as well. This is intended to show that you care so much about your customers success in using that product that you are willing to use it the way they are intended to use it. “Dogfooding” is thus shorthand for actually depending on something that you make yourself for sale.

item.title: Every day
item.description: Once upon a time I had a daily deadline to write 500 words. Anything was fair game as long as it was spelled correctly and included the two words “Ann Arbor” prominently in the lead paragraph. Those days are gone, but the memory of them reminds me of just how much hard work it is to have something new to say every day that’s worthy of publication. There’s a certain rhythm to writing every day.

item.title: Abandoning analytics
item.description: I’ve stopped for the most part watching and caring about how many people view the various bits of writing I do. The analytical tools out there for measuring the net have their primary impetus the selling of advertising, and as such they have slowly but surely morphed to be less and less useful for the discovery of non-commerical intent. It used to be that Google Analytics would tell you the exact search terms that someone used to get to your page.

item.title: That new system smell
item.description: That new system smell is what you smell when there’s a brand new blank page and you have a ready approach to fill it up. It’s the well-worked out technique just waiting for some new set of tasks to tackle. Some times new systems present as “greenfield” opportunities, with brand-new things to do that don’t require much in the way of adherence to what’s gone on in the past. Others show up as “brownfields”, with their fair share of underground surprises and an acrid or pungent smell of previous toxins or old tailings.

item.title: Small wins
item.description: I am reminded again of Karl Weick’s work on “small wins”, the observation that large problems are so large that we are overwhelmed just in thinking about them. It can be incredibly powerful to have a series of small wins that provide some momentum and that set you up for increasing confidence and capability to tackle bigger issues. My small win of the moment is getting this blog post up, reminding myself that once upon a time I met a writing deadline every day for publication, and knowing that it’s not necessary for every single post to be a big thing.

item.title: ISO 8601 date format and keeping track of weeks
item.description: Warning: objects in calendar are closer than they appear. I can never keep track of the day of the month, it seems. The watch on my wrist has a day marker, but it wants to have a 31 day month, and when we have 30 or 28 day months the day has to be manually adjusted. On the other hand, I have a keen sense for what day of the week it is.

item.title: Happy leap second (or mostly happy) and happy new year for 2017
item.description: Happy new year, and from a technology perspective, also happy leap second. [image: timekeeping for the leap second, from FSM Labs] Here's a complete picture of #leapsecond 2016. pic.twitter.com/DFp6XgnPig — FSMLabs (@FSMLabs) January 1, 2017 As always, when there’s a leap second, people get a chance to debug their timekeeping code. I guess if they happen frequently enough the code will get better exercise and some bugs will be shaken out.

item.title: Watching containers with Portainer and Sysdig
item.description: [screen capture: csysdig running inside Portainer] Run @sysdig CLI tool "csysdig" inside of a @portainerio console window. Nice way to watch @docker and @coreos cc @mckartha pic.twitter.com/hJGiHuJwKs — Edward Vielmetti (@vielmetti) December 29, 2016 The question to be answered is how to manage Docker containers - not just how to get them running, but also how to poke inside them while they are running to see what they are doing and make sure that you can make sense of what is happening while you develop or run in production.

item.title: Trip report, Tectonic 2016.
item.description: The Tectonic Summit was a conference in New York City in December 2016, hosted by CoreOS, with the theme Enterprise Kubernetes. Mohan Kartha and Edward Vielmetti went there as a guest of Packet, a bare-metal hosting provider in the city. This report details highlights of the presentations at the event as well as accounts from attendees of what they thought was missing from the presentation and discussions. Kubernetes Kubernetes is an orchestration system that runs on top of a container system like Docker.

item.title: Optimal Opera
item.description: I’m testing out using Opera instead of Chrome as my browser of choice, as recommended by Ernie Smith. So far so good. He notes that Opera is “basically Chrome (same engine) minus the battery drain”. My experience to date bears that out, though it’s in the early stages yet. The first thing I noticed is that memory usage for Opera is way less than for Chrome. That’s a big deal for me because I’m often noticing that this MacBook Air is in the red zone for memory with Chrome.

item.title: Derp Learning
item.description: “Derp Learning” is a categorization of the mistakes that “deep learning” techniques in artificial intelligence tend to make. It’s a typo, but also a deep insight into how complex systems fail. Some examples to illustrate: Deep Neural Networks are Easily Fooled: High Confidence Predictions for Unrecognizable Images, 2014. Nguyen describes “fooling images” that deep neural networks misclassify after being trained with a training set. These images are straightforward to construct and will fool the network with high confidence.

item.title: Static vulnerability analysis tools for Docker containers
item.description: You’re developing in Docker, and you have a container with a lot of layers when you’re done. How do you make sure that you don’t have security vulnerabilities hiding somewhere inside there, especially if you are running a container that depends on something that depends on something that depends on something else? The first step is to understand your own application, so that you can have some sense for how the dependencies that you have control over are impacted.

item.title: Using SDR.HU to listen to AM radio sports
item.description: The Cubs won the pennant, and the Buckeyes lost to Penn State. I was able to listen to the radio calls of both of these through recievers connected to sdr.hu. The Cubs radio call was from WMVP-AM, ESPN Chicago 1000. I had some practice listening to them through the Farmington Hills, MI SDR run by KB8SPI. That system is a KiwiSDR with a PA0RDT Mini-Whip, and it tunes from 0-30 Mhz including all of the longwave (broadcast AM) band.

item.title: More 96 core benchmarks
item.description: Yesterday I spent some time with a 96 core ARMv8 server. On day two I figured out a couple more things about that server. First and foremost, the extended path of installing Docker on the server I chronicled yesterday ended up being much easier today. A simple apt-get install docker.io did the right thing to bring Docker 1.12.1 into the system. Don’t do apt-get install docker on Ubuntu; you’ll get “docker - System tray for KDE3/GNOME2 docklet applications” instead.

item.title: 96 cores hot with ARMv8 and Docker
item.description: I had early access to a 96 core, 128 gigabyte ARMv8 server today. Here’s what I did to get all of the CPUs and all of the memory in use at the same time. The system: a bare-metal hosting company is working on general availability of these ARMv8 (aarch64) servers. I got early access for beta testing. Talk to me if you’d like to know more. The software: These systems boot with Ubuntu 16.

item.title: AWS Lambda for Python with "Chalice"
item.description: Chalice is a microframework for Python for AWS Lambda, similar in spirit to Flask. What does that even mean? A framework is a set of libraries and coding conventions that makes development in a specific language for a specific task easier. That usually involves making some simplifying assumptions about the task you are trying to solve, and embedding those assumptions in your code so that you don’t have to spell out quite as much detail to get a task done.

item.title: AWS IoT to Node-RED
item.description: Duong Dinh Cuong (on Github as cuongquay) has contributed a node for Node-RED that encapsulates the AWS IoT service and allows straightforward communication between the two systems over MQTT. The node, node-red-contrib-aws-iot-hub, includes support for the message-passing part of AWS IoT using MQTT, allowing you to open a channel to the IoT service and publish or subscribe to message topics. The result is easy integration between the two systems. As a part of this process, the node includes support for AWS certificates that have to be installed “just so” to allow AWS to trust Node-RED.

item.title: Narrowband IoT (NB-IoT) as a low power cellular data protocol on the u-blox SARA-N2
item.description: In the process of looking at embedded radio components, I came across the u-blox SARA-N2, a low power device designed to provide low bandwidth cellular data coverage for Internet of Things devices - “low power consumption and extended coverage” being the operative buzzwords. Speeds are 227 Kbps down and 21 Kbps up, and it’s claimed to be “low power” though no specific power consumption figures are provided. It’s built on NB-IoT standards that are standardized in June 2016 by the 3GPP project and which are codified in their Release 13.

item.title: sdr.hu and the emergence of lots of small wideband SDR receivers
item.description: sdr.hu is the home base for OpenWebRX, a remote spectrum monitoring system written by Andras HA7ILM. The system is designed to allow OpenWebRX servers, running on RTL-SDR or HackRF hardware, to share their radio spectrum and allow remote tuning of the available radio bandwidth. A typical installation will allow up to four remote listeners to independently tune in, and the tuning filters allow the listener to independently control the bandwidth of the receiver.

item.title: Writing assignment, 500 words
item.description: The writing prompt is simple scaffolding: write 500 words about what you’re working on right now, so that when someone asks what you do, you have a proof point of it. This is preparation for going to a conference where proof of professional identity is the whole point of the exercise. The thing you say you’re working on should be elaborated on at the top of the page, and any supporting details that don’t fit into the narrative should be omitted.

item.title: Daily coffee and wifi, September 6, 2016
item.description: Coffee and wifi (double espresso over ice) at the “dog park Biggby”, Platt Road at Ellsworth. It’s not an inconvenient location, and the very large south-facing windows are good to know about as the days get shorter. More than 90 degrees outside, and I’m preparing to make dinner. The recipe is for “broccoli Calabrian style” from Martha Rose Shulman. I couldn’t find that exact recipe online, but this Bucatini Con Broccoli Alla Calabrese is close.

item.title: September 3, 2016 Oklahoma earthquakes
item.description: A magnitude 5.6 earthquake rattled oil country in Oklahoma on September 3, 2016 at 7:02 a.m. The quake’s epicenter was eight miles northwest of Pawnee, OK. The USGS maps of the quake are detailed. The Pawnee Nation declared a state of emergency after ordering evacuations of damaged buildings in the area. Historically, the incidence of earthquakes in Oklahoma is low, and there is concern in the state that these earthquakes are of man-made origin.

item.title: New month, new theme
item.description: I’ve switched themes in this weblog, using Casper from Valère JEANTET who ported it from Ghost to Hugo. The biggest advantage of the theme is that it’s neat and clean and looks like other people’s work. The biggest disadvantage is that I have 80+ pages of paginated weblog going back into the dim mists of time, and this theme doesn’t come out of the box with support for that kind of deep back list in it.

item.title: full stack plane spotting and data analysis
item.description: The task at hand is simple. Whenever a particular airplane is visible overhead, send out a tweet with that notice. Don’t repeat yourself with this announcement more than twice an hour, but try not to have too much lag in reporting. The full stack of hardware and software to do this is not particularly complicated to use once you get it all running, but there are a series of issues and observations along the way that add to the complexity.

item.title: Plane finding with dump1090
item.description: In March 2015 I wrote briefly about plane spotting with dump1090. In short, many airplanes have ADS-B transponders which squawk out their location, airspeed, and current conditions, and you can pick up those transmissions using an inexpensive RTL-SDR tuner stick and a simple antenna. I’ve been looking into this again to see if I can get a better understanding of how it works as well as to take advantage of a year plus of software development.

item.title: Github private repositories
item.description: Github has changed their pricing strategy to allow individual accounts to have more private repositories. This is a welcome change for accounts like mine. As part of their change, enterprise pricing has increased. I’m told that this will multiply the bills that some companies will see. This post tests a new private repo, and links to Github pricing for future reference.

item.title: A commonplace reader
item.description: Sometimes it’s easier and faster to fill a page by quoting from others. The commonplace book is the annotated scrapbook, carefully collecting bits from other writers with just enough commentary and selection to make them your own. If these were written in this era you’d call it “curation”, though I can only think of that word in the context of “curated meats”, somewhat salty and dry and meant to be preserved for some time.

item.title: Bots are hot - again
item.description: The title of the post is taken from a 1996 Wired article by Andrew Leonard describing the state of automated systems in the dot-com era. Web robots – spiders, wanderers, and worms. Cancelbots, Lazarus, and Automoose. Chatterbots, softbots, userbots, taskbots, knowbots, and mailbots. MrBot and MrsBot. Warbots, clonebots, floodbots, annoybots, hackbots, and Vladbots. Gaybots, gossipbots, and gamebots. Skeleton bots, spybots, and sloth bots. Xbots and meta-bots. Eggdrop bots. Motorcycle bull dyke bots.

item.title: Mechanical slaves and the Californian ideology
item.description: Noted elsewhere, saved here for reference, from Richard Barbrook and Andy Cameron, THE CALIFORNIAN IDEOLOGY If human slaves are ultimately unreliable, then mechanical ones will have to be invented. The search for the holy grail of Artificial Intelligence reveals this desire for the Golem a strong and loyal slave whose skin is the colour of the earth and whose innards are made of sand. As in Asimov’s Robot novels, the techno-utopians imagine that it is possible to obtain slave like labour from inanimate machines.

item.title: Prince
item.description: Yesterday’s radio was full of the Prince music catalog. The artist passed away in his Minnesota home at the age of 57. In response any radio station that had anything other that pre-programmed music responded by playing his hits - “Little Red Corvette”, “Raspberry Beret”, “Purple Rain” - and the radio stations that had artistic control also played B sides, live shows, bootlegs and whatever they could find. Ann Arbor’s own WCBN was exemplary in this regard.

item.title: Upgrade to El Capitan
item.description: I’m working through the details of an upgrade from Mavericks to El Capitan. Some running notes. The upgrade took about 2 hrs. I went to the Apple Store at Briarwood in Ann Arbor to get the install done, since their Internet is faster than my home UVerse. After doing the upgrade the next big slow task is brew update. You would not be surprised to know that I have a lot of packages installed, and that brew is working hard to update everything.

item.title: Chicken and onion curry
item.description: Saveur Magazine has a recipe for a chicken and onion curry from January 27, 2010. It took a little more than an hour to cook, but the results were very much worth it - delicious, and worth repeating. We had the meal with rice, kale, and a daikon raita from food.com that I kind of liked but which was not a big hit with the rest of the table. The current meal planning regime here uses a Google calendar and a question at the end of every meal: do you want this again, and how many weeks before we have it again?

item.title: a2b3 lunch non-summary for 3d week of January 2016
item.description: Thanks to everyone for coming to lunch. We had 16 people, and complete introductions in 23 minutes. The topic of the question was “repair”. Linda Diane Feldt is repairing her side door, original equipment on a 90 y/o house. Kathryn Sanderson darns socks. Dan Friedus wants to know if you want to repair his 1980s Bolens garden tractors. (Make an offer.) Ruthann Nichols teaches Science and Wine as a freshman seminar at the U.

item.title: Ann Arbor area APRS network status, January 2016
item.description: APRS is the “Automatic Position Reporting Service”, a system for sharing information about the position of participating amateur radio stations. Clients transmit position reports on 144.39 Mhz; digipeaters repeat these reports to other monitoring stations; and various IGate sites monitor transmissions and send their findings to aprs.fi which collects worldwide data. In recent memory there has been an APRS digipeater in Chelsea, Michigan with wide area coverage, good enough to pick up travellers on I-94 west of Ann Arbor.

item.title: Dave New N8SBE to speak at ARROW on Software Defined Radio
item.description: Dave New N8SBE will be speaking at the January 2016 meeting of the ARROW radio club on the topic of Software Defined Radio. He will present an introduction to GNU Radio and the GNU Radio Companion visual programming environment, and the HackRF One Software Defined Transceiver from Great Scott Gadgets. The demo will include a disucssion of receiver and transmitter flow graphs, as well as resources to learn more about digital signal processing using the HackRF One and GNU Radio.

item.title: Oxford Flood Network
item.description: The Oxford Flood Network is making a flood detection network in the UK, using low cost sensors and volunteers. They are sharing their code on Github and their results on the Flood_Network Twitter account. They encourage you to join their effort, and no high technology is necessary. The network incorporates both readings from automated sensors (about £250) as well as manual readings from gaugeboards or photos. New as of December 2015 is an interactive flood map.

item.title: How I turned 99 cents worth of kale into half a gallon of delicious ice cream
A visit to the Computer and Video Game Archive, @umcvga
item.description: Previously: University of Michigan Computer and Video Game Archive (CVGA) Fifth Anniversary I had a chance to spend some time at the U of Michigan Computer and Video Game Archive tonight, with J in tow (or perhaps I was in tow). We played for about two hours in total, and then adjourned for dinner to talk about new and classic gaming and game emulation. He snuck in a few games of Tetris on his phone afterwards.

item.title: Santa visiting Swede's Diner, Ann Arbor, December 1950
item.description: Santa visiting Swede’s Diner, Ann Arbor, December 1950. From the Ann Arbor District Library “Old News” collection. Original caption: Stockings wouldn’t hold the Christmas cheer served up by Leonard Carlstrom, proprietor of a lunch counter at 208 S. Fifth Ave., so he used cups. Carlstrom played his own version of Santa Clause this morning when he hung up the “free coffee” sign to old customers and newcomers alike. “Business kind of picked up a little,” Carlstrom noted.

item.title: Platforms for the Internet of Things, 2015 edition
item.description: A discussion on one of the lists I follow covers the question of “platform” support for the Internet of Things. Since consumer IoT is a kind of squooshy market right now with rapid changes in prices and no one obvious choice for what technology to adopt, it’s worthwhile taking some kind of review of the landscape for 2015 and sort out what to watch for next year. This is organized by vendor, and loosely grouped so that similar systems are next to each other.

item.title: Douglas E. Vielmetti, plant engineer
OpenVPN scaling
item.description: Previously: OpenVPN in a container Also previously: Split tunnels considered harmful I have this running in a staging environment and a test environment; it properly isolates OpenVPN from the underlying operating system, and seems to do the right thing performing rather well. However, its biggest limitation is that it runs on a single host & thus provides neither high availability in the case of Amazon funkiness nor scalability to handle lots of clients.

item.title: I am eating a sandwich, with a recipe in Github
item.description: Twitter is, of course, for telling people that you are eating a sandwich. That’s been the point of the system the whole time - long before selfies, even long before it took pictures at all, you might get a proper narrative of what people are eating for lunch or a snack. Using the net to keep track of food is an old tradition; I need only point you at the Usenet Cookbook, developed from 1985 to 1987 by Brian Reid, as an archetype.

item.title: Thanks to everyone for birthday wishes, 2015 edition
item.description: Thanks to everyone for birthday wishes this year. It is increasingly clear that the place to go for birthday greetings is Facebook, which is absurdly efficient both at providing “happy birthday” messages as well as acknowledging them. Additional greetings came in via email, Skype, Twitter, and paper mail (hand written!, complete with reply postage!) Lunch at a2b3 was a Thursday event, with 14 at the table at Blue Nile. The topic of the conversation was roughly “places to take a walk outside in the winter”, and the dog-owners among us amended to include “with a dog”, and we got a pretty good list that I want to get onto Arborwiki.

item.title: Requesting meeting minutes under the Open Meetings Act
item.description: I’ve been frustrated in the past at the slow pace of getting meeting minutes through Freedom of Information Act requests. Queries to the City of Ann Arbor routinely get the full round of routine delays, with several cases where I’ve had to wait 15 business days to get routine meeting minutes. As it happens, there’s an alternative to asking for minutes, using the Michigan Open Meetings Act directly as your guide.

item.title: Kodi, formerly XMBC
item.description: I’ve been looking at Kodi as a possible software core for home media player for the living room. We have a whole rack of CDs and a shelf of LPs from our music-buying days, and I miss being able to listen to them. Kodi is the software formerly known as XMBC, and XMBC is still the name of the foundation that supports the work. It runs on most systems, and there are several distributions of it specifically for systems like the Raspberry Pi.

item.title: Dave Farber talk at Stanford
item.description: In this talk at Stanford, “Backwards towards the Future”, Dave Farber goes over some Internet history on the way to suggesting some necessary features of the future network.

item.title: Split tunnels considered harmful
item.description: Previously: Considered harmful essays considered harmful, Eric Meyer, 2002; also Go To Statement Considered Harmful, CACM, 1968; also Encyclopedia of things considered harmful, from cat-v.org. Split tunnels are a VPN construction where instead of sending all of your traffic for the network in a single encrypted tunnel that collects everything, you instead route some traffic down the encrypted link and other traffic goes in the clear through your default connection. It’s possible that you might have a tunnel configuration with multiple splits if e.

item.title: The productivity oscillator
item.description: I have been using Github issues for a long time as a todo list tracking and general productivity tool. It works well enough that I’ve opened over 4000 issues and have closed most of them. The perpetual management challenge is in deciding how many issues is OK to leave open. Put too few in, and it feels like you have things to do that are not written down; put in too many, and you’re likely to have duplication and you forget what it is that you were trying to do in the first place.

item.title: Kicked out of Nextdoor
item.description: Subject: Recent Tweet about Nextdoor Hi Ed, My name is Michael and I work at Nextdoor. Recently it has come to our attention that there isn’t a Nextdoor for your neighborhood, and that you have registered in a nearby Nextdoor neighborhood. Thank you for your interest in joining Nextdoor and becoming part of your community on our website. However we do need people to register at their real addresses, as it helps us add a sense of accountability, security and transparency to the website.

item.title: Help Wanted, Ann Arbor City Administrator, via Craiglist
item.description: As seen on Craigslist. City Administrator (Ann Arbor) compensation: $150K/yr employment type: full-time Ann Arbor City Administrator Job Responsibilities Feed Council Members information on a bi-weekly schedule, sometimes more frequently. Remind Council Members of basic stuff like how object permanence is an actual thing. Respond appropriately when Council Members insist “I can do it all by my self.” Respond appropriately when Council Members say “I don’t know how, you do it.

item.title: October 2015 food inspections for Washtenaw County
item.description: Every month or so the Washtenaw County Health Department releases the previous month’s health inspection reports. These are published to the county’s contracted web service, and a copy of those is extracted for the Food Inspections service designed by Wayne Eaker. There are 272 inspections for October 2015 and 50 more for November 2015 available. Here are some of the low lights of this month’s round of inspections, places where you might want to think about twice before making a visit.

item.title: First snow of the 2015 season
item.description: The first snow of the 2015 season for Ann Arbor happened today, November 21. The forecast is 6 to 10 inches. Roads are slippery, and there are reports of a number of crashes and cars in the ditch on area freeways. I’m listening to the Washtenaw scanner on Broadcastify and it’s a steady stream of road run-offs. Farmers Market was busy but snowy. Holiday greenery was well in evidence. We picked up smoked lake trout, cabbage, garlic, rapini, and a cookie and a donut for my market companions.

item.title: OpenVPN in a container
item.description: A few notes on setting up OpenVPN in a container. I’m using CoreOS, which gives me Docker 1.7.1 in the “stable” branch. Two different Docker configurations are available that take on this task, with slightly different setups. Kyle Manna’s docker-openvpn is what I’m working with; it in turn is derived from jpetazzo/dockvpn which solves the same problem slightly differently. There’s a tutorial on Digital Ocean that describes the setup including client-side support.

item.title: Stage lighting protocols
item.description: Some notes on stage lighting protocols and networks. Helpful reference pages: Ujjal’s DMX512 Website - protocol information, tutorials, how to etc. DMX512.com, the Entertainment Technology Website. Open Lighting Project Standards bodies USITT Lighting Some protocols Art-Net is DMX512 over UDP. libartnet is an implementation of Art-Net. There’s much much more, but this is a start.

item.title: Enjoy the attic while you can
item.description: Our attic is a three season room at best. In the depths of winter it’s really cold, and in the summer time it can be very hot. There’s a nod towards climate control but it’s a long way from the furnace and the space is just not really practical to equip as full fledged living space. I have a work table up there (where I am now) with some tools, a few working shortwave radios, a couple of mostly working computers, and a fair measure of junk.

item.title: Write one paragraph, floss one tooth
item.description: The a2b3 lunch today was at Madras Masala, we had a crowd of 10. I had a question about productivity - “what do you do every day” - and the answers were a good mix of attempts to be diligent and questions about whether narrowly focused productivity was even a good goal. The small productivity approach that has stuck with me is BJ Fogg’s “Tiny Habits” approach, which he writes about on http://tinyhabits.

item.title: Alpine, old school email
item.description: alpine is an old school Unix mail user agent. It first arrived on the scene as pine in 1992, and when it appeared I remember how happy I was that there was finally a mailer that I could hand to people who had never seen Unix before and that they would get it and be productive on their 14.4 kb/sec dialup modems. alpine appeared in 2007 as a rewrite of pine with Unicode support and a new Apache license.

item.title: Summer 2016 construction plans for M-14 near Ann Arbor
item.description: MDOT plans to do major road construction work on M-14 in Ann Arbor between Main Street and Miller Road during the spring and summer of 2016. A construction start date has not been set yet as of November 2015. In addition, bridge work will reduce M-14 to one lane between I-94 and Miller Road, and betwen Main Street and US-23. A detailed set of plans is available on the MDOT web site and in a helpful brochure.

item.title: Can I give up on LinkedIn yet?
item.description: I’m thinking about deleting my LinkedIn account. I was an early adopter of LinkedIn back when it first got started. It was interesting, fun, cool to collect all your friends. Now, my sense is that my LinkedIn profile is useless at best and actively unhelpful at worst. Why would I want to publish a standardized autobiography of work experience in a medium that doesn’t reward complicated life histories? It’s not helpful - what’s more, it’s not clear that it’s ever been helpful for the narrowly defined task of getting work.

item.title: A Localwiki for Jackson, Michigan
item.description: There is now a Localwiki instance up and running for Jackson, Michigan. See https://localwiki.org/jackson/ for the details. Like any Localwiki just starting out, it is woefully incomplete. You’re welcome to contribute to it, especially if you have some local knowledge of the area. The site was seeded with a handful of articles that had been created from the adjacent Arborwiki, and while it’s starting up we’re using the Arborwiki Facebook page to help push things along.

item.title: Ann Arbor's The Melting Pot is closing
item.description: The Melting Pot in downtown Ann Arbor is closing as of today, November 16, 2015, according to a post on the restaurant’s web site and a story in MLive. The last regular inspection of The Melting Pot by the Washtenaw County Health Department was on May 26, 2015. It turned up 11 violations, and some of them would be the sort of problems that would make you not want to go back.

item.title: FOIA update for tonight's City Council meeting
item.description: It seems that my pattern of going to public meetings includes writing FOIA requests during the meeting, to try to unearth some details of a matter observed at that meeting. Here’s a brief update on some FOIA requests in progress. Washtenaw County Health Department. I’m temporarily stymied in my quest to determine how often restaurants ask the county to change their inspection reports before they are published. An initial request came back with an estimate of $6000 to comb through every file in the department; an amended request looking for only 30 days of records only limited the cost to $1000.

item.title: Every day people
item.description: I admire people who can tackle an ambitious task every single day. Heck, I even admire them for doing some kind of nuisance task that still needs to be done every day. My every day challenge is to write. It’s easy to get off that habit if you make too much of it, and it’s way too easy to endlessly read the endless Internet, mutter under your breath about how foolish it all is, and not write down your bit of foolishness in return.

item.title: When the FOIA request costs too much, ask for less
item.description: I asked for some documents from Washtenaw County, and they estimated that it would cost over $6100 to produce the records. Apparently the nature of the request was such that they would have had to review 1200 separate files each individually on paper to determine a response. I didn’t have a $6100 line item in my budget to pay for it, so the best charitable response is “no thanks”. There is a question that I want to get at, though, and I think it’s attainable for less than $6100.

item.title: Minutes and agendas
item.description: The City of Ann Arbor planned 49 public meetings last month; 5 of them were cancelled. Of the remaining 44, 25 have meeting details posted to the city’s Legistar calendar, and 19 have no record of the meeting beyond its date. City boards and commissions and committees that routinely meet without publishing minutes or agendas to Legistar include the following: Cable Communications Commission Commission on Disability Issues Council Administration Committee Council Rules Committee Downtown Area Citizens Advisory Council Downtown Development Authority Elizabeth Dean Fund Committee Human Rights Commission Park Advisory Commission Dog Park Subcommittee Of these, the Downtown Area Citizens Advisory Council and the Downtown Development Authority post minutes to the DDA’s web site.

item.title: Open Github issues and open source projects
item.description: As a first approximation, the number of open issues on an open source project that uses Github to track its issues is a metric of software complexity and project maturity. It’s always worrisome to look at a project that has very few issues, because that’s usually a signal that no one else is using the code. Every bit of software has incomplete features that prompt a request, and bugs looking for a fix.

item.title: Open City Hall and government by survey
item.description: Ann Arbor’s “Open City Hall” is a survey instrument used to gather answers to multiple choice questions. Municipal officials - it’s not clear who - put together questions, and citizens are encouraged to tell the city what they think by providing answers. It’s run by Peak Democracy, which provides this same service to a number of municipalities. The current question under review is development on the Library Lot in downtown Ann Arbor.

item.title: Halloween Twitter vs Facebook
item.description: The two online social networks that consume idle cycles for me are Twitter and Facebook. They really shouldn’t be all that different, but of course they are. Halloween Twitter for me was full of football, ranging from idle banter about the score to full-on intense #goblue insanity as the game went down to its final moments. (The Team won, 29-26, after The Other Team made a crucial mistake at the end).

item.title: Medium, pretty but disappointing
item.description: Medium is a hosted blogging and discussion board at http://www.medium.com . It’s run by Evan Williams, who built Blogger. The site is very pretty and functional, both for writers and for readers. Authors get a lovely HTML based editor to write their text in, and readers can do highlights and annotations. From a purely technical point of view it’s one of the better systems for typing into on the net.

item.title: Slack vs IRC
item.description: IRC is an old-school multi-system, multi-channel, multi-network chat infrastructure. It dates from the 1980s, and was inspired in part by the BITNET RELAY systems that effectively sent messages from mainframe to message over virtual punch cards. RFC 1459 described the protocol in 1993. Slack is a shiny new system also providing multi-channel, multi-network chat. It’s very much a product of the 2010s, emerging in 2013 after being used for an internal communications channel at a games company.

item.title: Ann Arbor City Planning Commission Executive Committee meetings
item.description: The Ann Arbor City Planning Commission has an “executive committee”. The names of committee members are not published on the city’s web site, nor are they noted in an obvious place on the city’s Legistar system. From time to time, the Executive Committee holds a meeting to discuss matters of public import. These meetings are public meetings, and the announcements of their times and locations are duly noted on the public posting boards inside City Hall.

item.title: CubicSDR, a cross-platform software defined radio
item.description: CubicSDR is a software defined radio system for Mac, Linux, and Windows. It’s at version 0.1.4-beta as of August 28, 2015, and you can download the binaries from https://github.com/cjcliffe/CubicSDR/releases/tag/0.1.4 or the source code from Github at https://github.com/cjcliffe/CubicSDR . My point of comparison for software defined radio is GQRX. When you put CubicSDR on the screen it has a very pretty waterfall display and relatively easy to sort out mouse commands, but it’s lacking some of the fancier controls that a more mature program like GQRX has accumulated over time.

item.title: The AAATA MicroAPI
item.description: I had a good conversation with Prabal Dutta today about the sort of infrastructure you need to build a very simple bus tracker application for the current iteration of the AAATA’s online system. The desired goal is actually fairly simple: for a single place, identify the approximate location of a bus on a single bus line that serves that place, and alert the rider in time so that they can walk (or run) to catch the bus.

item.title: sudo port upgrade outdated
item.description: Macports is a system for bringing 3d party software to the Mac under some kind of organized control. Rather than randomly downloading binaries or sources, you pick from a wide variety of software that’s already been ported with all of its dependencies carefully noted. The process of bringing lots of software online inevitably means that when one system gets updated there are ripple effects up the stack until the software you had been using stops working.

item.title: Diligence
item.description: There are a lot of little boxes to type into on the Internet. Twitter and Facebook will gladly accept your text and send it out into the world. Medium is there if you want to be high minded, and Slack will let you narrow your message to a choice few. And there’s always Github issues, any of thousands of projects will accept a comment on an issue, real or imagined.

item.title: Over the top networks
item.description: I’m giving a talk on Over The Top Networks at the Radical/Networks conference in Brooklyn this weekend, October 24-25 2015. I don’t know exactly what I’m going to say in what order yet, but… the best way to predict that is to write down some notes. So here we go. The premise, briefly stated, is that most successful networks run “over the top” of existing working networks, and that you can learn a lot from what goes wrong along the way when the underlying network fights back.

item.title: The state of the city, Ann Arbor, fall 2015
item.description: A perspective on Ann Arbor area local government, as seen from fall 2015. The top level view is that local units of government are struggling with their technology investments, having a difficult time keeping them working, and are unwilling or unable to commit to any sort of “open data” initiatives as a result of their difficulties with basic operations. Some examples will illustrate. The City of Ann Arbor keeps track of a wide range of planning and permit documents through a vendor system called eTrakit.

item.title: August 2015 food inspections for Washtenaw County
item.description: Every month the Washtenaw County Health Department releases reports from a previous month’s inspections of restaurants in the county. Restaurants are typically inspected twice a year. The inspector looks to see that the state Food Code is enforced, with a particular eye towards identifying violations that result in increased risk to the public of food-borne illness. Wayne Eaker has put together a searchable and browsable database of these inspections, which is online at food-inspections.

item.title: How to squash a commit in git
item.description: If you are working on a project in Github, your work isn’t always linear. Sometimes the change you make doesn’t work completely, so you back a little bit of it out and move forward on a next part. It may take some hacking and sawing (and testing of course) to get a change that just works right. Projects like to have contributions, but project maintainers don’t like to insert noise into their efforts.

item.title: Snap CI
item.description: Snap CI is a cloud-based continuous integration system. Like Travis CI, which I have written about here, it lives in the cloud, lets you run programs triggered by GitHub commits, and offers a testing environment for free for open source projects which lets you familiarize yourself with the system before deciding to pay for it for your non-open-source efforts. I’m looking at all of these tools now because this weblog is now managed through a process that involves checking things into Github, which makes it completely suitable for automation for common tasks every time I save a file.

item.title: AWS DynamoDB downtime, Sunday am, September 20, 2015
item.description: A distributed system is one in which the failure of a computer you didn’t even know existed can render your own computer unusable. Leslie Lamport, 1987 Amazon Web Services DynamoDB experienced downtime in the N Virginia availability zone early Sunday morning, September 20, 2015. As a result, a number of other AWS services inside N Virginia that depend on DynamoDB also had downtime. Companies and organizations that built services on top of those systems who didn’t have geographic load balancing were having problems as well.

item.title: Into the matrix with Travis CI
item.description: Travis CI is a continuous integration tool, a description which means nothing to people who have never used it. “Continuous integration” is one of these industry phrases that doesn’t serve to illuminate the problem that it describes. Why would you care? Well, you’re working on a project with a bunch of other people, and it’s kind of complicated. It might depend on some old code that’s fragile and should be tested all the time when it changes, or it might depend some brand-spanking new code that doesn’t quite work and you know it doesn’t work yet but you want the test system to be less tedious.

item.title: Zeno's Inbox
item.description: Zeno’s inbox: cut in half in an hour; it always takes an hour to cut it in half, no matter how few messages there are in it.

item.title: Old code and old tools
item.description: One of the problems with old codebases is that they are missing modern tooling for automated builds, automated testing, and the like. A second problem with old code is that the maintainers (absent modern tooling) may not know or recognize what dependencies they have. If an old package is not mostly self-contained, it’s likely to have dependencies on other old code. This makes it hard to build, as those older dependencies have either gone offline or have mutated so that the old package doesn’t work with the new releases.

item.title: Writing up your tweets
item.description: I use Twitter regularly, and will frequently post short things there that reflect some 140 character slice of what I’m thinking about. That’s very quick, but at some level deeply unsatisfying, because how much can you put into 140 characters? Never quite enough. The challenge is to write up your tweets into something longer. Take the quip and turn it into a lead paragraph, then expand the lead paragraph into three or five or fifteen or fifty more.

item.title: Bluetooth and bluez inside Docker
item.description: If you have a Bluetooth device attached to a Linux system, it’s not clear how to attach that device to a Docker container on that same system. bluez, the Bluetooth driver for Linux, uses the D-Bus to communicate. This is more complex than a FIFO or socket interface, and thus less easy to obviously say how it should be mapped into the Docker processs and file system space. The references below show several ways of not doing this task, and hopefully at some point will get answers on how to do it.

item.title: xml2json as part of a web parsing pipeline
item.description: The problem, simply put. You have a messy, real world HTML page; you want to parse it to pull out some key element of it, to pass along to some other task; you want that parsing pipeline to be as compact as possible, because you’re running on a small machine, and you’re doing the task frequently, and because the page may change out from under you at any time. Clearly this is not an optimal task to have, but you live with the web you have, not with the web you want to have.

item.title: Managing a Raspberry Pi OpenVPN with Salt
item.description: When you successfully install something complex, and then you fail to document one small thing about how you did it, the inclination is to over-document once you get it working again; thus, this expository account of managing a set of Raspberry Pi devices using the “salt” system. It’s not a complete start to finish writeup, just a pointer to the bits that I had forgotten. This is mostly experimental at this point, and the collection of devices is relatively small.

item.title: Deep web
item.description: I think this whole “deep web” thing is mis-stated for the most part. Since forever there have been Internet-based services that have been unreachable to the public unless you had some kind of specialized access. Private internal networks are the norm at companies of any size. Calling that the “hidden web”, “deep web” is non-sensical in that it’s not really hidden to anyone who has proper access to it - it’s just that you (and Google) don’t and won’t have that access.

item.title: Over the top networks, a history of building new systems on the wreckage of the old
item.description: This is a copy of a proposal for a talk at the Radical/Networks conference. The original proposal is on Github. The event runs October 24th and 25th (Saturday + Sunday) from 10a - 7p at NYU Poly in Brooklyn, NY. Title: Over the top networks, a history of building new systems on the wreckage of the old New networks often feed off of old ones, in ways that characteristically draw energy from aspects of those networks that are easy to take over and hard to defend.

item.title: Terabytes, at least in theory
item.description: I have a new terabyte drive. It’s impossibly small, impossibly cheap, and just fast enough to accomplish astounding backup tasks in what seems like not enough time. It is, however, a mass storage device that depends on rotating magnetic media, and as such it’s obsolete. The drive cost less than $50. For about 10 times that right now, I can buy another terabyte drive that is solid state rather than spinning oxide storage.

item.title: RRDTool v1.5.4 on Raspberry Pi
item.description: The second in a series of efforts to get a suitable database for the task. The challenge is that there’s a lot of data out there that changes all the time, and you want to gather it, make sure it’s sane, squirrel it away for later analysis, put together a pretty chart so that you can spot check it, feed it into other systems not yet fully dreamed of to cause actions, and so on.

item.title: First pass at MongoDB
item.description: Somehow I never learned SQL along the way. At various times I have learned enough of the database lingo (inner join, outer join etc) to know where I missing things, and I have a lot of experience with common Unix tools (grep, sed, awk) and some newfangled tools (jq, csvkit) to be able to turn a big pile of data into a smaller pile of data. But I don’t have database chops per se right now, and sometimes that’s a limiting factor on projects when the data sets are too big.

item.title: Listening to Radio Havana Cuba via a shortwave software defined radio
item.description: I’m listening to Radio Havana Cuba via a shortwave listening post set up with a software defined radio. The system, Great Lakes Listening Post, has four separate radios covering the 80, 40, 30, and 20 meter bands, all fed into the WebSDR software from PA3FWM. It’s located in Michigan, and thus approximates the radio reception I’d get from my own receiver. R Havana Cuba is a good station to listen to.

item.title: Summer dinner
item.description: Dinner: roasted red peppers, roasted green beans, boiled potatoes, cool and crunchy red pepper and yellow tomato salad with balsamic, kale, and either eggs or bratwurst depending on your preferences. I really prefer cooking in the summertime! Discussion on Facebook.

item.title: GQRX based radio scanner with gqrx-scan
item.description: gqrx-scan is a Perl script that drives the remote control of the gqrx software defined radio receiver to turn it into a scanner and automated recording tool. The GQRX remote control protocol is well documented and fairly simple, which means that the bulk of the Perl script has to do with setting and getting options. You can drive your scanner from the GQRX configuration file, or you can monitor a specific band or range of frequencies.

item.title: Using Github Issues and Waffle.io as a personal kanban board
item.description: I’ve been using Github issues to track my personal todo list for quite some time now, and since November I’ve been using Waffle.io to help that process. Waffle in this use is a view of a series of queues in my todo list. Most everything that I’m not doing now lives in the “backlog” queue, which I try to keep to less than 100 just to keep myself sane. (At more than 100 there’s usually a lot of duplicates; at less than 100 I’m probably not acknowledging that there’s something to be done).

item.title: August 2015 Farmers Market report
item.description: At Ann Arbor Farmers Market: Red Haven peaches 🍑, potatoes 🍠, kale, green onions, tomatoes, red peppers, and a cherry snow cone for my shopping companion. (Testing to see how the emoji comes out; I didn’t see a kale emoji.)

item.title: Ashley and Madison, Ann Arbor
item.description: At the corner of Ashley and Madison in Ann Arbor is the Washtenaw Dairy. Ashley Street is named after “Big Jim” Ashley, an Ohio congressman and promoter and builder of what became the Ann Arbor Railroad. Madison Street is presumably named after President James Madison, as a number of downtown streets have presidential names. There is an Ashley, Michigan in Gratiot County between Owosso and Alma, on the route of the railroad.

item.title: Liquid contact indicator tripped
item.description: Fortunately, a lot of parts were replacable, and the ones that didn’t need to be replaced were returned intact with all of their data on them. Back in business. I am happy to have paper notebooks and to know how to use them, and to also have good enough backup systems that I didn’t panic. There are a few very small things I need to learn, mostly about Github and how to manage subprojects.

item.title: Ann Arbor City Council Preview for 17 August 2015
item.description: Ann Arbor City Council meets at 7:00 p.m. on Monday, 17 August 2015. A preview of the agenda is on Arborwiki, complete with a map, on the tag 2015-08-17CCMTG. Some highlights to note: The consent agenda includes $36,412 for the purchase of 21 Taser weapons. This is a sole-source purchase, to replace weapons purchased in 2003. Also on the consent agenda is $83,000 for a sole-source purchase to renew the CityWorks license, which is used for asset tracking and maintenance of city owned resources.

item.title: Tianjin explosion
item.description: This passage from the English language Wikipedia has been repeatedly removed from the narrative of the explosion in Tianjin, China. Chinese authorities reportedly attempted to censor professional and social media reports. Social media users have reported that their posts regarding the blasts are being deleted, with the words “Tianjin” and “explosion” having become the most censored on Weibo. Journalists were kept away from the blast site. It was also reported that eight hours after the explosion, Tianjin Television was not reporting on the event, instead showing soap operas.

item.title: Zeno's inbox
item.description: It took me about an hour to half-empty my inbox. Alas, I have Zeno’s Inbox, which is never emptied, only half-emptied.

item.title: a2b3 lunch non-summary for the Broken Egg
item.description: Lunch at The Broken Egg with the a2b3 crew. We had 17 people show up, which is about 2x what had been the normal attendance. The restaurant was very accomodating, and everyone was well fed. Organizing lunch is the highlight of my week. Lots of things were discussed, here’s a few of them: The Perseid meteor shower peaked last night, notes Linda Diane Feldt, who saw a few shooting stars from her cabin in Lyndon Township.

item.title: long form
item.description: Too much of the stuff that I write is very short. I’d like to sort out how to have more long form writing. From memories of times past trying to do this, the struggle was in coming up with structure. It’s easy to push out a 5 paragraph essay in comparison with structuring a 20 or 50 or 200 page tome. I know that people have taken blogs as first drafts of long form writing, and heaven knows I have enough raw word count to start to make something from.

item.title: All watched over by machines
item.description: As it turns out, a detailed look at the way you spend time over the course of a day online yields several fascinating conclusions. As previously noted, Wakatime is the introspective tool of choice. Gee, that’s a lot of time to look at Facebook, Twitter, and Gmail; Why aren’t you spending more of your productive time writing; I’ll bet that if you put down the computer your day would be more productive.

item.title: a2b3 lunch non-summary for August 6, 2015 at Mi Compadre
item.description: The a2b3 lunch this week was at Mi Compadre, a Mexican place on Packard. We had a good turnout. I recommend the lengua tacos. I was inspired this week for the lunch question by going to the Workantile lunch on Wednesday, which followed the same general pattern - sit down, introduce yourself around the table, and answer some simple question. At Workantile the prompt was simply “share something nice that happened to you this week”, and that was enough of a prompt for everyone to be brief and cheery.

item.title: wakatime, an automatic time tracker for programmers
item.description: Wakatime tracks your time if you’re a programmer. It does this by integrating into your favorite text editor (including vim) and your favorite source code maintainence system (including Github) and then matching time spent editing with checkins into your system. It collects stats behind the scenes and turns everything into a shiny dashboard. “Fitbit for programmers” is the tag line. That which is measured, improves. I don’t know if wakatime will improve your writing, or your coding, or your general state of mind.

item.title: Your new robo-assistant, Amy Ingram
item.description: Every day, computers are making people easier and easier to use. (David Tempkin, In Formation) x.ai has a new service in development, an automated personal assistant that helps you schedule meetings. You give it - or I should say “her”, because the bot’s name is Amy Ingram - you give Amy your calendar and some simple instructions, and “she” manages the correspondence with the person you’re trying to meet with.

item.title: I voted, summer 2015 edition
item.description: Ann Arbor is one of three peculiar communities in the state of Michigan to have partisan City Council elections; the other two are Ypsilanti and Ionia. This has in recent years meant that the races that decide the makeup of City Council happen in the summer when students are gone and when voter turnout is very low. I did vote, and I do plan to go to at least one of the parties celebrating victory or acknowledging defeat by the candidates who have the remaining funds from their campaign to put out a nice spread for supporters, hangers-on, or the perpetually politically curious.

item.title: expertise encapsulated into out of date memory banks
item.description: In the case of experts “writing down what they know”, and incorporating that data into an expert system or knowledge base. One of the challenges is expecting that the expert can write down everything that they know, all at once, in such a way that there’s no internal inconsistencies. The world usually works in such a way that it’s changing fast enough that an expert with a written memory bank of a certain size is always holding as “true” in that memory bank something that is demonstrably false, just because the world shifts out from under them.

item.title: Michigan Emergency Incidents and overnight storm report
item.description: Michigan Emergency Incidents is a news service that covers emergency dispatch around the state of Michigan. Members of a closed Facebook group post call-outs of emergency services operations, and there’s generally follow up from other members to note incidents in progress or news stories written from the scene. All information contained in MEI posts is to come from received radio transmissions heard directly from radios / scanners or via an online broadcast, verified reliable sources, or first hand knowledge (ie you are on scene).

item.title: Small multiples
item.description: James Corriea, Jr. has this nice illustration of the use of small multiples in weather forecasting to show the progression of forecasts as they change. Day 1 outlook progression #wiwx #miwx #ilwx #ohwx #inwx pic.twitter.com/HtLJQ6lOq0 — james correia jr (@jimmyc42) August 2, 2015 Better Know a Visualization: Small Multiples from Juice Analytics has some more examples - the original goes back to the work of Edward Tufte.

item.title: Blogrolls
item.description: A blogroll is a list of other weblogs that the writer links to, in the hopes that they will get a link back in return. It’s one way to establish yourself as part of a community of writers. The practice of keeping and maintaining a blogroll is completely gone, as self-linking networks like Facebook and Twitter have obviated the need for explicitly calling out those linkages. Our self-updating feeds simply stream a continuous loop of content into our willing eyeballs, interspersed with as many advertisements as we will stand.

item.title: Knolling
item.description: Knolling is the practice of organizing things neatly, especially to arrange things in parallel lines or at right angles. Thanks to Jason Kottke for the always be knolling idea and background info, which he attributes to Andrew Kromelow. For some inspriation see Things Organized Neatly, a Tumblr from Austin Radcliffe. More: Hannah Sitzer, Always Be “Knolling”—My New Favorite Word, Inspired by Tom Sachs, 2011. A Tom Sachs movie, “Always be knolling”, from Ten Bullets

item.title: mitmproxy
item.description: In his An internet x-ray machine for the masses, Paul Ohm writes a lucid introduction to mitmproxy, a man-in-the-middle proxy server that allows you to get between your browser and the Internet and poke at (and change) the traffic going between the two. http://mitmproxy.org is the home of mitmproxy. It’s the work of Aldo Cortesi and a cast of hundreds of contributors on github at https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy . I used the OS X binary distribution from the download page.

item.title: Soundcloud, now and in the future
item.description: If you have exactly one copy of something and it’s only on Soundcloud, this would be an opportune time to make a backup. That’s always a good idea anyway not to rely on single web servers for anything, but it’s especially notable in the light of these articles. First, the upbeat Bloomberg Business article of July 10, 2015: … SoundCloud’s potential is fascinating, and perhaps unique. The founders have ambitious goals that respond to changes in the way music and sound are created and consumed.

item.title: Favorite times for twitter
item.description: Favorite times to twitter: Late evenings (basically, now) when the West Coast early evening crew comes to life. Early mornings, when Europe is awake. Least favorite is mid-day Eastern time, when there’s a lot of noise.

item.title: a2b3 lunch non-summary at Blue Nile for 30 July 2015
item.description: Nice lunch today at the Blue Nile. We had 10 people for lunch, including two people (Azita Azadi and Tom Meloche) who had moved back to town from far away. I had the vegetarian plate which was delicious (love me some injera). The question of the day was regarding postcards, something I’m thinking about quite a bit. With a modest (but still too big) amount of effort I can launch a postcard from the command line of my Mac.

item.title: First round of postcards
item.description: A first round of postcards sent via Lob.com have arrived or are nearly arrived at their destinations. The initial experience of sending them made it clear that I need to do some simple user interface improvements. I think I can cope with the current situation on producing the card back photo, but again there’s more work to be done making the text on the page wonderful. A reasonable question is, why do you send them?

item.title: We should do more blogging
item.description: Blog every day, whether you want to or not. Pick a topic, learn it well, and write about it as you learn it. Or pick a topic you know really well already and teach to it. Sometimes you can do both. The time spent blogging can’t be any less worthwhile than time spent on Facebook or Twitter. The exchange is, instead of clicking the like button and the favorite button, you actually have to think a little bit and write something down that makes sense.

item.title: restaurant inspections
item.description: Every month the Washtenaw County Health Department does a round of restaurant inspections. Wayne Eaker built an importer that pulls in data from the site that hosts the official county inspections, and is storing the inspection data on Github to make it easier for the next person who wants to build a nice interface to all the data. Wayne was good enough to find a spot to host an interface to this data that lets you browse through it; you can find it at

item.title: Tomatillo
item.description: I bought a little box of tomatillos from Argus Farm Stop. The question now is what to do with them. Suggestions so far include: fried like green tomatoes, slice thin, coat with a thin batter roasted them with onions and jalapenos and make into a salsa raw tomatillo salsa a la Rick Bayless fried with onions and then add to scrambled eggs for tortillas baked shrimp with tomatillos, feta, and cilantro carne en su jugo, a la La Fiesta Mexicana in Ypsilanti in pastel de Montezuma What I ended up making was a very simplified version of Tomatillo Breakfast Tacos, reducing the recipe to just onions, tomatillos, and eggs.

item.title: make tidy
item.description: I’ve been converting over old postings on this blog from Typepad. The data export and import was imperfect, and this meant that I’ve been poring over the data to figure out what keeps and what goes and what-not. It’s a chance to review old words. One of the artifacts of the old hosting platform was a helpful at times system called Zemanta. Zemanta would figure out what you were writing about and give you helpful suggestions for related links, both to things that you had written as well as to things other people had written.

item.title: Daily coffee and wifi at Argus Farm Stop
item.description: Daily coffee and wifi at Argus Farm Stop, outside in the sunshine under a lovely red umbrella canopy. Espresso over ice and a day-old olive twist. The view is of a Sky Trak lift at the construction site across moving materials to the back of The Mark, a building that’s going up where the car wash used to be. The news of the day is a death on State Street.

item.title: Starting a trial of Little Bird
item.description: Little Bird is a system that helps you discover influencers and experts in any topic. I’m at the very start of a 7 day trial. Marshall Kirkpatrick is CEO of Little Bird, and he has been active on Twitter posting interesting ideas about influence marketing - and given that it seemed prudent to give the product a try. Pricing is aimed at agencies, not individuals, so I’m going to look at this product through the eyes of people doing “social listening” for a living, tracking the messages that appear on a topic and either quietly making sense of what is happening or actively engaging with those people to try to influence their opinions.

item.title: Library notes from Malletts Creek
item.description: Out for a bike ride to Malletts Creek Branch Library after a delicious lunch of BBQ at Ricewood. One of the challenges of low overhead custom postcard making is getting an image manipulation pipeline that kicks out photos that a appropriately cropped and sized. The latest challenge is identifying the single command line that will turn a photo from my phone’s camera into an appropriately sized image for the card with a minimum of cropping, distortion, and manual file transfers.

item.title: Docker Detroit, Wednesday July 22, 2015, 6:00 pm, Troy, Michigan
item.description: I hope to see you at Docker Detroit’s kickoff meeting, to be held at RIIS, 1250 Stephenson Highway, Suite 200 in Troy, MI starting at 6:00 p.m. tonight July 22 2015. I’ll be coming in from Ann Arbor. The venue is between 14 Mile and Maple behind Beaumont Hospital. Google Maps suggests that because of construction on I-75 in that area you might want to head north on Campbell instead of taking the I-75 / I-696 interchange north.

item.title: Daily Coffee and Wifi, Roos Roast Wednesday edition
item.description: At Roos, an espresso over ice with a little half and half and a hard boiled egg. It’s a very compact breakfast. The espresso is served in an appropriately sized glass mug and tastes like the strongest little iced latte you will ever have. On my Mac, run ‘boot2docker upgrade’. That gets me up to current 1.7.1 revision of everything. Edwards-MacBook-Air:~ emv$ docker version Client version: 1.7.1 Client API version: 1.

item.title: bocker is a subset of Docker in 100 lines of shell script
item.description: bocker is Docker (or at least a good sized subset of it) in 100 lines of shell script. I suppose the point is that even though there’s a huge world of hype surrounding containerization as a next step of systems management, when you get down to it, it’s just not that complicated.

item.title: Coworking notes at Elixir Vitae
item.description: A productive afternoon with Mohan Kartha in which I opened a great many tabs in Chrome. This bit of writing to close those out. Elixir Vitae is a great spot for writing - lots of quiet noise from the coolers to keep a background hum, and close to the bus station. I’m sorting out the simplest task that I’d like to do with Node-RED, now that I have a Raspberry Pi 2 running it under Docker in a configuration that’s reliable enough that it seems like it’s stable.

item.title: Daily coffee and wifi, ERC South Main
item.description: Espresso over ice at ERC South Main. This is now my favorite summer drink. Served in a cup with enough ice and you get the makings of a very strong iced latte, just add a little half and half. The work of the morning is finishing up yesterday’s work on sending postcards with Lob.com. Key to this effort is resizing your favorite images so that they meet the template. Fortunately I had the presence of mind seven years ago to write up my notes on using sips and Imagemagick for image manipulation and that helped.

item.title: Commuter North and South
item.description: A bus labeled “TRAINING”. Don’t take that one. Kayakers in bright yellow kayaks on the Huron River under the bridge on Fuller Road. Would it be too much to ask to have wifi actually on the blue bus, or is it more reasonable to expect that people have cell data coverage everywhere and that wifi on the bus is for long haul buses like Megabus? I’m happy that with Hugo I can have a reasonably complete local blogging environment completely independent of having Internet access, so long as I have my computer with me.

item.title: Daily coffee and wifi at Biggby Packard
item.description: It’s a warm but pleasant mid-summer late Monday morning, and I’m visiting the first cafe inbound on a walk to town. Biggby Packard is where I end up when the inbound bus schedule timing is just so. Summertime cafes near campus are odd. There’s not really enough here to motivate someone to drive here for coffee, so it draws people from the surrounding neighborhood and from the athletic campus. I’ve been in here before when I was the only patron for more than an hour but this morning there’s a few more people sitting typing.

item.title: lob a postcard: printer sends cards via API
item.description: Lob.com has an API to send postcards-as-a-service ($0.70 per each, full custom both sides). Details at https://lob.com/services/postcards . It works, but all of the user interface is up to you; if you know a good service for delivering a single full-custom postcard with postage that actually has a user interface and not an API for less than $1.00 each, let me know and I’ll update here. I’ve started checking in a few tiny utility programs that exercise the Lob API.

item.title: espresso over ice with a little half and half
item.description: A simple recipe that you can order from your favorite barista: an espresso shot over ice. Leave enough room to add a spot of half and half. Cold, refreshing, and very strong. To try: a shot of espresso over shaved ice. I think this is doable at Ann Arbor Farmers Market where you’d go to the stall where a granny is selling shaved ice, and then walk a plain snow cone over to the Roos Roast stand for your espresso shot.

item.title: The weak ties of your social network are its greatest strength
item.description: Lior Zoref has a new book out called Mindsharing: the art of crowdsourcing everything (Portfolio / Penguin, 2015). I have a copy of it from the Ann Arbor District Library which was on the new shelf at Mallett’s Creek on a sunny and hot summer Sunday afternoon. Mallett’s has good air conditioning, a very good spot to be on a warm day. The challenge of a book like this is picking out the good bits without repeating the author’s technique of using the word “Mindsharing” (capitalized) at every opportunity.

item.title: Remembering Hazen Schumacher of Jazz Revisited
item.description: Hazen Schumacher was a radio broadcaster who hosted the popular “Jazz Revisited” show on NPR and Michigan Radio (WUOM) for 30 years. He died on July 18, 2015. Arborwiki’s page on Hazen Schumacher has memories of him and his program. The jazz collection that he assembled and all of the master tapes for the show are now at the Jazz Museum Bix Eiben Hamburg, and 24 editions of the program are up online for your listening at http://bixrevisited.

item.title: Notes on the Midland G-227 GMRS/FRS radio
item.description: Midland G-227 GMRS radio, quantity two, a gift from the Wells-Becker Motorcycle Emporium in Dexter, Michigan. I replaced batteries in both of them, they take 4xAAA. Radio 1 successfully hears static when the (M) monitor button is depresssed; Radio 2 hears nothing. A manual is at http://www.manualslib.com/manual/396326/Midland-G-225.html which describes the frequencies of the 22 channels it can transmit on. A reasonable next step is to get my NooElec SDR tuner out and see if I can monitor a transmission.

item.title: food coop notes for July 18, 2015
item.description: Some notes over a cup of coffee and some cold roast chicken. I need to mix up my menu selections at the coop more so that I can remember what I was writing by what I ate; I usually eat the same thing! Peter Honeyman and Lynn Chamberlain were here at the coop, doing the NY Times crossword. (Saturday crossword in 36:05, a mid-day triumph.) At Farmer’s Market: cherries, parsley, kale, potatoes, dill, tomatoes.

item.title: Levenshtein distance for approximate match
item.description: The problem, simply stated, is that of typoes and inconsistent spelling and pluraliziation. Let’s say you have a collection of text that you want to annotate with some metadata, like categories and tags. You don’t want to set aside ahead of time exactly which tags you want to use, but you want to catch through some test or lint step that you’ve done something wrong by typing “apples” into a field that really has “apple” most of the time.

item.title: The Checklist Manifesto, in checklist format
item.description: My Checklist Manifesto summary (of course in checklist form) THANK YOU @Atul_Gawande http://t.co/PfsIMwcCiB pic.twitter.com/ZfzP72RgiF — Remo Uherek (@remouherek) July 4, 2015

item.title: Detroit Sound Conservancy: Greystone Jazz rescue
item.description: The Detroit Sound Conservancy went to the vacant Book Building in Detroit on July 7, 2015 to salvage the collection of the defunct Graystone International Jazz Museum. There’s a nice writeup in MLive, Graystone jazz artifacts, forgotten in Detroit skyscraper, now being preserved. Photographer Doug Coombe went along to document the effort with a photo set on Facebook. “We knew that things were bad,” said DSC’s Founder and President Carleton Gholz about the neglected collection, but Gholz didn’t know how bad until he discovered many of the former museum’s records were broken and strewn across the floor.

item.title: valuable archives or just fishwrap
item.description: You’re writing away, and you hit “publish”, and the thing you pieced together flings its way through the ether to some audience, real or imagined. The next day it’s nearly impossible to find again unless you manage to produce the precise incantation into a search engine.
