There is some long-lasting trail, to be sure, easy enough to dredge up if someone is motivated by money or curiousity, but for the most part the social networks of today (Facebook, Twitter) generate most of their energy from capturing the attention of the moment.

item.title: custom views of taxonomies
item.description: One of the motivation ideas behind going to the work to move a big weblog to a new platform is to get better control over categories. With Typepad, every category looks about the same; the idea now is with Hugo I can have separate categories that look different. For instance: There are a number of recipes in the collection, which should be sorted alphabetically or by key ingredient, not chronologically.

item.title: a2b3 lunch at Ayse's, Art Fair 2015 edition
item.description: Eight of us met for lunch at Ayse’s today. It was a normal Thursday in that regard, as that’s a pretty typical size for the lunch group these days. We talked at question time about how we get big chunks of time to work on projects. One answer was to work early in the morning or late at night when there were fewer distractions. Gyll, a remodeling contractor, mentioned the use of checklists to make sure that the things that needed to get done got done.

item.title: diligently editing and converting for production
item.description: I’m trying my best to get this blog ready for production. The tasks remaining include the following. Get a reasonable home page with pagination. Somehow I need to provide some kind of access to almost 2000 posts, and they don’t all fit on a single page. Sort through the design to make old things reachable, and then worry next about the formatter. (This is done at least minimally, though the provided paginator interface uses a list structure that’s not nice.

item.title: a great many things
item.description: This weblog, which may or may not ever see the light of day, is about a great many things. There are other blogs waiting to be written that don’t have that infinite vista; they could easily be much more narrow. What, then, do you write about? Let’s count some of the options. Docker on the Raspberry Pi, following Hypriot’s lead. Just Docker in general, and Dockerizing various things. Recipes, since I have a bunch already.

item.title: the hugo cookbook
item.description: Every technology for publishing eventually gets used to publish recipes. This collection of mine here is not an exception. I’ve marked up the recipes with the “recipe” category, and also created a “recipes” taxonomy with ingredients. It’s sort of like a subcategory but not really…well it is as long as I am careful about it. Previous attempts to do this include The Usenet Cookbook (from mod.recipes), alt.gourmand, and most favorite in my book the use of Gopher as a cookbook.

item.title: sweet potato cauliflower soup recipe
item.description: Some sweet potato cauliflower soup recipes: Allyson Kramer likes hers with a bit of garam masala: http://www.allysonkramer.com/2011/10/sweet-potato-cauliflower-soup/ Our Three Peas wants carrots and celery and chicken stock: http://ourthreepeas.com/sweet-potato-cauliflower-soup/ Food.com and “Kelly in TO” calls for curry and cinnamon: http://www.food.com/recipe/cauliflower-sweet-potato-curry-soup-246992 Our meal plan pairs this with biscuits and kale, and it was delicious!

item.title: Publishing from Hugo to Github Pages
item.description: One of the challenges in getting things started is figuring out where the end product is going to live. Hugo has its own web server which is pretty nice, but since it generates static pages, the results can really go anywhere. This tutorial goes through the process in excruciating detail http://gohugo.io/tutorials/github-pages-blog/ but somehow fails to make it easy. What I’d like is a publishing workflow that just like the normal Hugo workflow puts things online instantly once they are built.

item.title: Mac and Goat
item.description: Mac and Goat calls for goat cheese; we generally use a goat gouda or a goat cheddar, both of which are usually available at the local Trader Joe’s. Feel free to substitute any hard cheese that melts well in your recipe. The dish also calls for rice pasta, but again feel free to substitute; you’re aiming for something like a rotini which handles the sauce well. Preheat oven to 375 degrees.

item.title: customizing a theme
item.description: Themes can be customized by editing the top matter, or by directly changing the theme. The challenge is understanding enough of how the moving parts interconnect to make it do what you want it to do, or at least enough of them so that you don’t have a blog that just looks like a weak ripoff of someone else’s. This tutorial http://discuss.gohugo.io/t/creating-a-minimal-working-template/135/13 does a very nice job of helping you walk through the simple bits.

item.title: converting typepad to hugo
item.description: The task of the night was getting a few years worth of Typepad posts into Hugo. My first step was to convert to Jekyll format, which I did using this typepad_to_jekyll Ruby gem: https://github.com/koozie/typepad_to_jekyll You then need to do a few things to get the Jekyll files exactly right for Hugo: Change the date format Rewrite the Categories Download and relink all of the images Changing the format for “date” was a one-liner in perl with the -i (“edit in place”) flag.

item.title: lunch with jonathan
item.description: Jonathan and I went to Paradise, a Vietnamese place in the Colonade that also serves Chinese food. He got Mongolian Beef, and I got pho deluxe. It was perfectly adequate if not spectacular. The topic of conversation was an elaborate storyline in a game that involved animatronics in a creepy Chuck E. Cheese type abandoned pizza parlor. We then went to the Malletts Creek library, until about 4:00 p.m. I worked on Hugo and constructed a theme from scratch.

item.title: wow that is fast
item.description: So 634 pages from my Github Gollum based Wiki markup all got imported into Hugo and it rendered all of them in 828 ms, or basically under a second to pull in everything I’ve ever written. Astonishingly fast. Alas, those files while they are in Markdown are not really ready for direct import, since they have [[double brackets]] everywhere that get uglified. The other limiting factor is the date marker that’s not included with them so they all show up as January 1, 0001 which is funny the first few times and then not funny.

item.title: Bringing up Node-RED and mosquitto under "docker compose" on a Raspberry Pi
item.description: Progress, actually quite a lot of it: The problem, neatly stated. Docker is good for bringing up single services ("microservices"), but sometimes your application needs more than one thing running for the whole thing to work. Enter "docker compose", formerly "fig", which automates the process of running various Docker commands in the right order with the right arguments all driven from a configuration file. As described by their documentation: Compose is a tool for defining and running complex applications with Docker.

item.title: gooseberries at Ann Arbor Farmers Market
item.description: Wasem's brought gooseberries to today's Ann Arbor Farmers Market. There were two varieties, one with smaller berries and one with larger berries. Delicious just as is.

item.title: Ann Arbor City Council for July 6, 2015: online video stream goes dark
item.description:
If you're trying to follow Ann Arbor City Council via the online feed, you'll be disappointed tonight as the feed is not working.
The CTN live stream for channel 16 is currently down and being looked at. Sorry for the inconvenience. #ctnannarbor — CTN Ann Arbor (@CTNAnnArbor) July 6, 2015

item.title: The Verge turns off comments
item.description: Of course you never read the comments, but you might read the commentary on the comments. Here's The Verge's decision to turn off comments on its stories for the summer: And sometimes it gets too intense. What we've found lately is that the tone of our comments (and some of our commenters) is getting a little too aggressive and negative — a change that feels like it started with GamerGate and has steadily gotten worse ever since.

item.title: "Reddit is going up in flames"
item.description: Drama on Reddit - a key employee has left the organization, and the side effect has been chaos. Reddit's popular AMA (Ask Me Anything) and other subreddits have gone private, and the top post today is TIL After mismanagement, Digg, a company that had been valued at over $160 million sold for a mere $500,000 and the second to top post is a link to the demise of America Online's Community Leader Program page on Wikipedia (via Wikiwand):

item.title: Never read the comments
item.description: Your comments excluded, of course, dear reader, though there are more posts here than comments by people on those posts. The reference is to the interminable slog of newspaper comments which place a long stream of dreck at the end of that carefully edited story. I miss the days of carefully considered letters to the editor - when you could count on not every letter getting published, when you were limited to a certain number of words, and when if you were wildly off-topic your words might never see the light of day.

item.title: BBC: "Greece's bank holiday from hell"; impact on Bitcoin transactions?
item.description: From the BBC: Greece's bank holiday from hell. Greek banks are expected to stay shuttered for more than a week, and in the meantime depositors can only withdraw 60 euros per day. The Internet spin on this is to wonder how Bitcoin will be used to evade currency controls. From Financial Post, Bitcoin is the real winner in Greece crisis: The main driver for bitcoin prices seem to be Greek buyers.

item.title: A random walk through the rolodex
item.description: The evening's work can be roughly summed up as Generate a random item from my personal wiki that starts with 'A'. Much of the time, that will be a person's name. Comment on that person's weblog, if they have one, or otherwise get in touch. Repeat until 'Z'. In the course of doing this I came across an essay, otherwise unpublished, on "The algorithm driven day"

item.title: Using a squid cache to make automated data collection a bit less rude
item.description: squid is a web caching system. Instead of browsing directly to a site, you point your browser at a squid cache, and the cache serves up cached copies of the data you are asking for. If squid has an out of date copy of the data it fetches a new one for you. The goal is to be a transparent cache, and to be nearly as fast as direct access when you don't have the data, and way faster when you do.

item.title: SpaceX CRS-7 launch failure
item.description: June 28, 2015. The SpaceX CRS-7 resupply mission to the International Space Station failed this morning. The vehicle experienced an anomaly on ascent. Team is investigating. Updates to come. — SpaceX (@SpaceX) June 28, 2015 Awful. pic.twitter.com/m0ediJGzeg #SpaceX @NASA via @MickiMaynard — David Beard (@dabeard) June 28, 2015 More details live on NASA TV due at 12:30 p.m. EST, Sunday June 28, 2015. Wikipedia's SpaceX CRS-7 page is as good as you make of it.

item.title: from the WCBN collection, "Africa"
item.description: I'm volunteering at WCBN hoping very slowly to accumulate enough hours and enough time behind the mic to get trained as a DJ. It only takes time, which has not seemed to be plentiful as of late. Here's a photo of the African music collection there (just a portion of it, there's more).

item.title: Running DD-WRT as a switch on a Linksys WRT54GL
item.description: I don't really need more wifi access points in the house, but I do need more wired ethernet ports. Thanks to ellemef's box o'goodies I have a WRT54GL to play with, and I put DD-WRT on it set up in a configuration to run as a switch plugged into my existing ATT UVerse router. I got the DD-WRT firmware loaded by following the provided directions. Then I followed the instructions at You are here: DD-WRT wiki mainpage / Linking Routers / Switch for configuration.

item.title: Gogs, a self-hosted Git server
item.description:
Gogs is a self-hosted Git server, an alternative to using Github as a for-pay hosted service or Gitlab as another self-hosted system. It's written in the Go language, and is said to be sparing of system resources.
I'm building it using Docker on a Raspberry Pi 2, thanks to the folks at Hypriot; the writeup is Run your own GitHub-like service with the help of Docker, and the file on Dockerhub is at hypriot/rpi-gogs-raspbian.

item.title: running mjpg-streamer on a Raspberry Pi 2 with an old Logitech webcam
item.description: I followed the instructions on this post on LinuxMediaServer.net to get an old Logitech web camera running on a Raspberry Pi 2. Here are some of the changes I did from the original to support my hardware. lsusb returns this device: Bus 001 Device 004: ID 046d:08ae Logitech, Inc. QuickCam for Notebooks I had to add a driver for the camera: sudo modprobe gspca_zc3xx The camera I have shows up as /dev/video0 and has a resolution of 320x240:

item.title: Bree Newsome scales South Carolina capitol flagpole, takes down Confederate flag
item.description:
Reporting by Democracy Now, "This Flag Comes Down Today": Bree Newsome Scales Flagpole, Removes SC Capitol Confederate Flag
The state Bureau of Protective Services confirmed Newsome and one other person were arrested. They are charged with defacing a monument, which is a violation of state law 10-11-315. The law has not been used since it was passed in 2000 during another push to remove the flag from the capitol.

item.title: Do you believe in life after Facebook?
item.description: I've deleted Facebook from my phone, though I haven't closed out my account there. Look for me to be there less and here (on this blog) more. Facebook is a never ending stream. You start to look at it, and you are never done. There's never a "congratulations, you are all caught up" message to be found. It's just too big to make sense of, and too much of a potential time sink.

item.title: Docker 1.7.0 issues: problems with Mac and boot2docker, ARM, Ubuntu, and disk size of images
item.description: Docker 1.7.0 has been released into the wild. Every .0 release of software should be expected to have some issues, no matter how good the QA and automated test process. Here's what to expect if you're getting Docker 1.7.0 up and running. boot2docker on Mac On the Mac, with boot2docker: Docker certs not valid with 1.7 upgrade is issue 938 on boot2docker. The symptom is a message like this An error occurred trying to connect: Get https://192.

item.title: The law of the land
item.description: The opinion in Obergefell v. Hodges reads in part: No union is more profound than marriage, for it embodies the highest ideals of love, fidelity, devotion, sacrifice, and family. In forming a marital union, two people become something greater than once they were. As some of the petitioners in these cases demonstrate, marriage embodies a love that may endure even past death. It would misunderstand these men and women to say they disrespect the idea of marriage.

item.title: Reports (as of yet unconfirmed) of enforcement of laws against Uber drivers in Ann Arbor
Reddy Kilowatt
item.description: There's lots of Reddy Kilowatt information and memorabilia on ReddyKilowatt.org. This is a completely unofficial web site dedicated to Reddy Kilowatt. It features history, memorabilia, items for sale and more. Please note that I can’t/don’t/won’t estimate the value of any of your Reddy collectibles. Seriously. Ever. Try looking at the going price at eBay or at other antique dealers if you want to find out how much any particular Reddy Kilowatt item might be worth.

item.title: Simulating a power grid with RTDS
item.description: Noted as an example of "how do they do that" The RTDS simulates any user-defined electrical system with models of complex electrical components, such as transmission lines, generators and transformers. The components can be precisely defined to match your equipment characteristics. Through real-time simulation, your relay or control equipment is tested in closed-loop mode, acting on the simulated system as it would in the actual installation. Kinetrics has a page on RTDS describing how it's used.

item.title: a few notes from Dockercon 2015, as seen via Twitter
item.description: The annual conference for Docker, Dockercon, has been going on. A few highlights from the event as seen through Twitter - I was not there to attend it. Docker is real on the Raspberry Pi through support for the ARM processor. Awesome live demo of Docker on a Raspberry Pi by @Quintus23M in the #dockercon closing keynote. pic.twitter.com/DJfBtpcYws — Bridget Kromhout (@bridgetkromhout) June 23, 2015 More details from the presenter, Hypriot-Demo and challenge at DockerCon 2015.

item.title: Automating web testing and scraping with Selenium and the Firefox Selenium IDE
item.description: You might like me occasionally want to pull a bit of data from some web site and use that data in a script or process. Some modern web sites are fiendishly complex and don't have the data you want on a simple API or page that you can parse; instead, you're expected to navigate through a whole next of menus and links that present the data attractively. I'm making a go of tackling this task with Selenium, a browser automation system which can drive browsers like Firefox and Chrome and that can in turn be driven by programming languages like Python.

item.title: Using blitzortung.org and lightningmaps.org to watch lightning roll in
item.description: A brief note on two pages I refer to during severe weather, like the storms that rolled through the area on Monday night and Tuesday early morning that led to tornado damage in Manchester on the morning of June 23, 2015. LightningMaps.org has a zoomable near real time map of lightning strikes. You can zoom and pan around looking at locations of lightning strikes, with a small (less than 10 seconds) delay.

item.title: Using GNU Parallel to speed up network operations
item.description: My current laptop (a MacBook Air) has a plenty fast processor and super fast disk. This means that the usual bottleneck for system operations is the network, not the computer itself. I go from wifi spot to other wifi spot enough that I know that performance varies a lot, and especially there are a lot of places where the network is really not fast enough. Enter GNU Parallel. This little tool lets you spawn a whole series of processes, with the next one starting when the previous one completes.

item.title: Docker's new RunC doesn't (yet?) work on Mac OS X
item.description: Docker has a new runtime environment that they are releasing called runC. It's a "lightweight universal plumbing" that tries to encapsulate all of the Docker dependencies and infrastructure. To build Docker we have re-used large quantities of plumbing: Linux, Go, lxc, aufs, lvm, iptables, virtualbox, vxlan, mesos, etcd, consul, systemd… the list goes on. Because of Docker's start on Linux systems, it's been tricky to get it running under Mac OS X.

item.title: Governance and documentation and getting board documents online promptly
item.description: I attended this week's meeting of the Governance Committee of the Ann Arbor Board of Education, and this is what I saw. Two of the agenda items did not have any documents online in Board Docs before the meeting (revisions to 3000 and 4000 series policies). Those were added during the meeting. One of the agenda items (cyberbullying) did have a document online. It had several typoes and missspellings, including an incorrect reference to statute.

item.title: Golden Rose Little Free Library now open
item.description:
A new Little Free Library is now open at the corner of Golden and Rose in Ann Arbor.
From the owner: We hope that you'll stop by to share books that you have enjoyed reading and take a book that inspires you. Feel free to leave a note inside of the book for the next lucky neighbor telling them what you liked about the book. We hope to keep it stocked with books for kids, teens, and adults!

item.title: Arborbike, a first review
item.description: Plus: fun to ride, big front basket. It's a very nice bike that you're riding, with a good 3 speed shifter and a very sturdy construction. Minus: no lights, no bell, no helmets. More specifically, I am told that the lights come on automatically, and that there is a bell somewhere, but I didn't find it and it wasn't labeled. I did have a helmet with me so I wore that.

item.title: Juneberries are ripe
item.description: Juneberries are ripe in Ann Arbor on June 15 - I was able to harvest a few of them on North Campus by the Duderstadt building and on Central Campus by the detours around the Engineering Arch. Get them before the birds do!

item.title: Ann Arbor flooding on Sunday, June 14, 2015
item.description:
A severe storm dumped a bunch of water on Ann Arbor on Sunday, June 14, 2015. Here are reports of flood locations as monitored on Twitter. All times Eastern. 6:09 p.m. Huron River well down from its crest at 14.95 feet; flood stage is 16 feet, last observation is 13.57 feet at 5:15 P.M.
4:28 p.m. Huron River downstream from Allen Creek surged from about 700 cfs to over 2200 cfs in the span of less than an hour at about 2:00 p.

item.title: 410 Miller still stands
item.description:
Why is 410 Miller still standing, after the Building Board of Appeals issued an order for it to be demolished? In part, because the Notice and Order to demolish was never sent. From FOIA 15-210:
Further it is stated that the hearing at which the decision to demolish was made was recorded, yet a transcription of the hearing was not made available on account of the audio being illegible:

item.title: ARRL Field Day is June 27-28 2015
item.description:
Field Day is June 27 and June 28, 2015. In Ann Arbor the combined efforts of the ARROW and UMARC clubs will be at the Ann Arbor Airport. Come join in and get on the air.
For more details: Field Day information from ARRL shows what the event is all about. Field Day Locator will help you find one in your area.

item.title: DRAFT POLICY 5060 - STUDENT PARTICIPATION IN ASSESSMENT PROGRAMS
item.description: Note: this is part of the discussion at the Ann Arbor School Board meeting of June 10, 2015. You can see a full live blog of the meeting at Ann Arbivore which is written by former Ann Arbor Chronicle writer Monet Tiedemann. DRAFT POLICY 5060 - STUDENT PARTICIPATION IN ASSESSMENT PROGRAMS The Board of Education believes that assessing student progress provides important data by which the district can measure the effectiveness of curriculum and instruction and the impact of our educational programs on student achievement.

item.title: 5 June 2015: issues with Bing
item.description: I've switched my default search engine in Chrome from Google to Bing. Tonight Bing is having some hard times. The error message reads Ref A: 12e073d9654e42ca80ab3e9d2d4a7233 Ref B: C1D32273105299714FDB3F05BD068F80 Ref C: Fri Jun 05 19:37:20 2015 PST A few minutes later (at 19:50 PST) all seems to be normal. Awaiting a reason for what happened.

item.title: Just fix the fire hydrant, OK?
item.description: @A2GOV just fix the fire hydrant ok? — Edward Vielmetti (@vielmetti) June 4, 2015

item.title: Gin and rhubarb
item.description: As noted elsewhere, gin and rhubarb are said to go well together. Boozed and Infused has two recipes, one for Rhubarb Gin and one for Rhubarb Orange Gin. A Rhubarb Fennel Fizz is from The Year in Food. I am promised that if I provide the rhubarb, that gin will be provided to me. Can't talk about rhubarb without Rhabarberbarbara.

item.title: Making Lag Monster a bit less laggy
item.description: @tallervielmetti is using my old black Macbook. It's never been an exceptionally fast machine, but it's been super laggy of late, hence the name Lag Monster. I installed all kinds of crap on that machine to test it out, and never uninstalled a lot of it. It turns out that some judicious uninstalls seemed to help a lot to keep the load average down. Some hints to my future self if these ever re-emerge:

item.title: Building a dipole antenna for your SDR tuner stick from an old set of headphones
item.description: Some notes before I try to do the build. The parts I have or know I can get: cheap earbud headphones, NooElec NESDR Mini 2 SDR tuner stick with whip antenna, Nokia 635 phone, antenna from an older NESDR Mini SDR tuner stick. Parts I need: a short adapter cable that provides antenna in for the SDR stick as a headphone jack socket. The SDR tuner comes with an antenna, but I want to replace it with a dipole - especially one cut to have a center point for FM broadcast on 88.

item.title: Running Node-RED on a Raspberry Pi with Docker and Hypriot
item.description: My goal for the week was to empty out my inbox sufficiently that I would be able to make progress on some programming tasks that are hard to do when there's distractions. The inbox got all the way down to zero, and that meant that there was a chunk of evening time suitable for hacking. Happy to report that the result of this is Node-RED running on a Raspberry Pi under Docker on top of Hypriot.

item.title: Two repaired shortwave receivers in one day !
item.description: From the fix-it-yourself department, two successful radio repairs in one day. For my dad's old Kenwood R-2000, a replaced 100ma 5x20mm fuse brought it back to life. The antenna fuse search took a rather long time to get started, but the help of the UMARC club and Dean KD8VXR was enough to unearth the right part. For reference the Mouser part number is 693-0034.3107 for a Schurter fuse. For my old Sony ICF-2010, a fresh set of AA batteries for the computer was enough to get it going again.

item.title: The rented lakes of my childhood by Marge Piercy from Made in Detroit, Knopf 2015
item.description: The rented lakes of my childhood by Marge Piercy I remember the lakes of my Michigan childhood. Here they are called ponds. Lakes belonged to summer, two-week vacations that my father was granted by Westinghouse when we rented some cabin. Never mind the dishes with spiderweb cracks, the crooked aluminum sauce pans, the crusted black frying pans. Never mind the mattresses shaped like the letter V. Old jangling springs. Moldy bathrooms.

item.title: When is Ann Arbor going to have a full time building official?
item.description: The City of Ann Arbor does not have a full time building official, and the routine operations of the building department are suffering as a result. I was at a Building Board of Appeals meeting today, 14 May 2015. The group just barely met quorum and had just three members seated, with one member absent and one vacant position. The regular staff member who handles the meetings is on medical leave, and the building official who had been present at previous meetings (Ralph Welton) has left the city's employment under circumstances which have not been fully and adequately explained.

item.title: Summer 2015 Route 5 to Ann Arbor schedule, as embedded with ViewerJS
item.description: This is the AAATA Route 5 summer 2015 inbound to Ann Arbor schedule, as it looks as embedded with ViewerJS. I note on Chrome on Mac OS X that the map is white on black instead of the black on white that I see in Preview. Report is that this looks like a grey box on an iPhone. I note that on Windows Phone 8.1 it loads slowly and the fonts are very blocky, and the map is a somewhat legible black on white.

item.title: Clive James, "Windows is Shutting Down"
item.description:
From his collection "Angels over Elsinore", originally printed in The Guardian. Clive James, Windows Is Shutting Down. 

I howled with laughter first time I read it. Absolute genius. pic.twitter.com/cOs1ojHA3m — Andrew Wiggins (@alboreto) April 24, 2015

item.title: Disable Quiet Hours on your Windows Phone 8.1 so you always take that late night call
item.description: I have a new Windows Phone and overall I really like it. We bought it used and unlocked and it's running on the Ting network, which means that in addition to being an interesting device that looks really nice it's also quite economical. That said, there's one feature on the phone that wasn't a feature last night. I was making arrangements to take my son home, and was expecting a call from him.

item.title: Denton TX area tornado of 7 May 2015
item.description: May 7 2015 9:34p Eastern: Live coverage of Texas storms from WFAA 8 ABC "Confirmed tornadoes, hail hit North Texas". Twitter hashtag #txwx and weather service is @NWSFortWorth. Ann Arbor, MI, May 7 2015 8:42p Eastern: Listening right now to the W5NGU repeater on Broadcastify where net control is running an emergency net. Tornadoes on the ground with ham radio operators giving precise locations of the storms and net control calling out spotters to get reports.

item.title: Lyndon Township gas explosion, 5 miles north of Chelsea MI, near M-52 and North Territorial
item.description: Ann Arbor, May 5, 2015, 2:00 a.m. I spoke with Jim Payeur, fire chief for the Chelsea Area Fire Authority, about the gas pipeline explosion in a 20" gas transmission line in a wooded area near the corner of M-52 and North Territorial Road about five miles north of Chelsea, Michigan. The incident occurred at about 10:30 p.m. on May 4, when about 20 people reported a sound like a jet crash.

item.title: 2015 May 4 Ann Arbor City Council preview, in map form.
item.description:
Thanks in large part to the hard work of Dave Askins of Civ City, here's a preview map snapshot of the agenda for Ann Arbor City Council for May 4, 2015. Click through for detail which will take you to Arborwiki's accounts for each of those items tagged with the tag "20150504ccmtg".
This map reflects these agenda items: 590 W. Ellsworth Road African American Downtown Festival Allmendinger Park Ann Arbor Airport Ann Arbor Book Festival Ann Arbor Jaycees Fourth of July Parade: Routes Arrowwood Hills Cooperative Barton Sidewalk Project Cinetopia: Maynard Street Firecracker 5K Fire Station 3 Flagstar Bank: 3600 Plymouth Road Hands-On Museum Hunt Park Scio Church Sidewalk Project Traver Street Storm Sewer Project Knowing City Council, it's likely that one or more issues will emerge at the last possible moment, but this at least gives you a shot at figuring out what council actions are happening in your back yard.

item.title: 2015 Graduation Day Galesburg MI earthquake rattles Ann Arbor, Grand Rapids, Detroit on May 2
item.description:
May 2, 2015, ANN ARBOR, MICHIGAN: A magnitude 4.0 earthquake rattled southern Michigan at 12:23 p.m. today, with the quake centered at Galesburg, MI. Timeline May 2, 2015, 12:59 p.m. EST: Official report gives the quake ID us20002avh. "Did you feel it" map shows the range of the affected area.
May 2, 2015, 12:37 p.m. EST: No official report yet from USGS, but an earthquake rattled the southern half of lower Michigan at about 12:25 p.

item.title: Hudson Mills Metropark to Dexter 10K, B2B-West River Trail, Saturday May 2, 2015
Pothole or sidewalk? Substandard repairs to sidewalks using cold patch at State and Packard
item.description: Sloppy sidewalk repair state and Packard @a2gov cc @A2CivCity pic.twitter.com/GjDdOAL8rW — Edward Vielmetti (@vielmetti) April 27, 2015 Finding out more via this FOIA request Please send the following records: 1) All records pertaining to the repair of the sidewalk on Packard St at the intersection of S State St on the N side of the street, both east and west of S State St between Hill St and Arch St, with cold patch.

item.title: Cobblestone Farm Market Spring Kickoff May 3, 2015 430p-730p Good Shephard
item.description: After Water Hill, come to the Cobblestone Farm potluck.

item.title: Water Hill Music Fest, Sunday May 3 2015
item.description: Details of this music festival including a schedule at waterhill.org. I'll post a map here when I have it.

item.title: Reading and listening to the news in another language, Nepali edition
item.description: My command of the Nepali language is extremely limited, Somewhere on a bookshelf somewhere in the house I have this cookbook and its recipe for "gundruk", a fermented leafy vegetable that I have never tried to make and have not found to eat anywhere here locally. There is a lot of news from Nepal as a result of the tragic earthquake, and the thought goes to try to read at least a tiny piece of the news in the original language.

item.title: a2b3 lunch non-summary for 4th Thursday of April at Argus Farm Stop
item.description: A nice lunch at Argus Farm Stop. I bought bread for the table, John Harnois supplied hard-boiled duck eggs from Harnois Farm, and we had 9 at the table.

item.title: Big data, data analytics, and data mining
item.description: Big data is any data that you can’t analyze with the tools that are commonly known to you. For many people, that means a table bigger than what Excel can handle. What you consider “big data” depends on your capabilities and the tools and systems you have available to you. Sometimes people will be led down a weird path where problems that are straightforward to solve with one set of tools are also solvable with great difficulty with another set of tools; see Adam Drake, Command line tools can be 235x faster than your Hadoop cluster , for one illuminating instance of this.

item.title: The Calbuco volcano in Chile has erupted; 23 April 2015, early a.m. update
item.description: The pictures coming out of Calbuco are stunning, let me find a few to save them here. Local coverage is from biobiochile.cl: Volcán Calbuco retoma proceso eruptivo con expulsión de material incandescente Una densa columna de lava y material incandescente comenzó a desprenderse desde el cráter del volcán Calbuco pasada la 1:00 de la madrugada de este jueves, en lo que fue calificado como una reactivación abrupta del macizo.

item.title: Ann Arbor Earth Day / The tribe picks garlic mustard / And curses the snow
item.description: Props to ace editor Bob Needham for the haiku. Garlic mustard recipes from Friends of Silgo Creek include Garlic Mustard and Spinach Raviolis with Garlic Mustard Pesto, Garlic Mustard in Lemon Sauce, and Wild (Garlic) Mustard Seed Mayonnaise.

item.title: W8UM 145.23 repeater for Sunday night net, 19 April 2015
item.description:
As seen with gqrx on my Mac.
The readout on the radio says 145.2169 Mhz instead of 145.2300 Mhz, I think that means the receiver has drifted 16.1 KHz from peak, or perhaps the listed frequency is not what I'm looking at.

item.title: inbox 50, unread 500
item.description: So if you don't read email every moment of every waking day, you get a bit behind. Apologies to my correspondents if I can't manage same-day responses every day.

item.title: Daily telegraph: A new routine with the Argus Farm Stop and the Ann Arbor Y
item.description: Last week was spring break, so my routines were completely upended. The boys didn't have school and so I didn't actually have to be anywhere in the morning. Yet I was up and out of bed and awake by 7:00 a.m. and the weather was nice. Perfect weather to try out a new spring routine. The first piece of the new routine is getting to the Ann Arbor YMCA. If the weather is nice and I don't have anything else going on, it's a nice bike ride; if I'm making a car trip into town for school, it's close enough to be a good next stop.

item.title: 2015 Skywarn training
item.description: After three or four years of planning to get Skywarn training, this year I finally did it. The good folks at Washtenaw County Emergency Operations Center and at the National Weather Service in White Lake, MI did a training session at Pioneer High School. The class was concurrent with a Michigan ballroom dancing competition so there was music and festivities and accomplished looking dancers to enjoy before the class. I was there with John Hritz KD8MKE and Ann Hanson.

item.title: plane spotting; some quick notes on a new software-defined radio setup
item.description: A couple of years ago, I got one of the first-generation RTL-SDR USB software defined radio units. These inexpensive devices are originally designed as TV tuners, but clever radio hackers figured out how to turn them into software-defined radios that tune to a broad spectrum of radio. After some experimental use I managed to cook the original unit which in its death throes no longer listened. The vendor (Nooelec) generously offered a modest discount on my next purchase, so I took them up on the 2d generation unit.

item.title: The mysterious crash of
item.description: My Twitter feed was full of air crash news this morning. Germanwings flight 9525 crashed in the French Alps, killing all passengers aboard. Wikipedia has a good summary, perhaps as good as any. What was unusual about the crash was that there was no distress call, and that the plane descended rapidly and steadily into the ground without veering once from its course. Of note in this regard is another European flight on a similar aircraft some months earlier.

item.title: What's the most expensive parking space in Ann Arbor?
item.description: Last night was the a2civictech meetup. We met at Zingerman's Next Door, there were 9 people who showed up, some familiar faces and some new ones. The nominal topic of the discussion was data quality, understanding how various data sets that come from civic sources have noise in them and looking at ways to deal with that. The best story was that of a well map that showed a hill in the middle of a lake, because the underlying data set had two wells with the same name and the person who built the map picked the wrong data to map.

item.title: My new (old) phone is a Nokia 3390B
item.description: First made in 2002, these old candybar style phones are virtually indestructible. My son popped my Ting SIM into it and it's working fine. Not so my old Nexus 4, which did a face plant on the sidewalk, cracked the screen and screwed up the digitizer. It dates only from 2013. I'll price out fixing the Nexus 4, but I suspect it's not going to be worth repairing. (We'll see.) And then there's the question of what kind of device do you want to carry around with you all the time, how much you want to spend and whether it makes sense to retreat to simpler technology for a while until the answer is more clear.

item.title: Northern lights in northern Michigan
item.description:
Photo credit: Ryan Eby, from his aurora photoset on Flickr.
I first got word that there was a chance of northern lights from the Michigan VHF-UHF Society mailing list, an amateur radio group. When the aurora activity is high, the VHF amateur radio bands (2 meter and 6 meter) get increased range, so ham radio operators with this interest keep an alert out. The Aurora Page at Michigan Tech has a lot of useful links to space weather forecasts.

item.title: Strange Alaska
item.description:
This strange map of Alaska from the National Park Service annexes parts of Canada.
Thanks to eagle eyed Canadian Kai Petainen for pointing this out. Original at http://www.nps.gov/state/ak/index.htm, which is an embed of this full state map.

item.title: Obituary: Dr. Lewis Ernest Peters (April 10, 1932 - March 4, 2015)
item.description: Dr. Lewis Ernest Peters, 82, of Marquette, died peacefully Wednesday morning, March 4, 2015, at Brookridge Heights Memory Care while under the care of Lake Superior Hospice. He was born April 10, 1932, in Evanston, Illinois, a son of the late Lewis Ernest and Evelyn (Tehle) Peters. Lew married Katherine Kay Vielmetti in 1980 at the Marygrove Retreat Center in Garden, Michigan. He joined the faculty of the Biology Department at Northern Michigan University in 1961.

item.title: Cleaning polygons in R and Shapely
item.description: The project of the week has been an effort to generate a set of maps - 2935 of them, in fact. The source data is from the Department of Energy, listing a set of utility companies and the counties they cover; the goal is to have a boundary map generated for each utility company. I know it won’t be a perfect boundary (most utility companies have at least one county that they only provide service to part of), but as a start it’s a pretty good one.

item.title: Maps with Leaflet and LeafletR
item.description: style leaflet(data="/Users/emv/tmp/N.geojson",dest=tempdir(),popup="*",style=style) So, progress. One process, written in python, takes an Excel file provided by the county and creates a GeoJSON file from it. Addresses in the file are geocoded. The original file has a set of restaurant inspection reports and three kinds of inspection problems found; I add a fourth "score" variable that's derived in some way from those three. A second process (code above) is in R using the LeafletR graphing package.

item.title: R, me hearties
item.description: I've been fond of maps and graphs for a long time, but haven't had a good set of tools to play with that easily generate decent versions of same from various data sets I've found or accumulated. The small hope is that a little bit of hacking on the right tools will fix this. One of the tools of choice is R, a language for statistics and data analysis. It's tremendously powerful and a bit complicated, but I'm not trying to learn the whole thing; rather, I'm after just the barest minimum so that I can competently generate a scatterplot of data and place it onto a map.

item.title: super cold (but sunny; don't forget that it was sunny)
item.description:
One of my favorite weather forecasts comes from forecast.io. This screen shows the ensemble set of forecasts they have for temperature for tomorrow (February 20, 2015), highlighting the 8:00 a.m. reading.
You'll note from this graph that there are several weather models they are pulling from. The one of them that has the coldest predicted weather is RAP from the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colorado. Looking at their set of pages they have a nice cold temperature forecast map.

item.title: Designing a wearable magnetic sensor
item.description: I woke up this morning thinking about ways to improve my sense of direction. (Don't ask me why.) Here's some previous work on the internet that I had found for wearable devices that give you an always-on compass reading and some ideas for more. First, some prior art. How to make a tactile compass feedback belt is a typical design, with about $150 in parts. In short you wire up an electronic compass to a series of tiny cell-phone style vibrator motors, and you position a dozen or so motors along a belt.

item.title: Just how cold is that window? Winter monitoring with the TI Sensortag, Node-RED, and Freeboard
item.description: Our living room has lovely (old) wooden windows. When it's cold, the windows get cold. Last year we got some lovely thermal curtains to insulate. I thought I'd use some of the equipment I had to see just how cold the windows were and how much warmer the curtains are to the touch. The setup: Macbook Air running OS X 10.9 (Mavericks), Node-RED 0.9.1, Freeboard, TI Sensortag. I'm using RabbitMQ as my MQTT message passing system, but that's not strictly necessary for this application.

item.title: Psychedelic Rangers, Ann Arbor, 1972
item.description: The Ann Arbor Downtown Development Authority is considering hiring "downtown ambassadors" to patrol city streets, help out visitors, and keep the downtown neat and clean and welcoming. As a counterpoint to this corporatized welcoming function, I give you the Psychedelic Rangers, a project of the Rainbow People's Party (1972) which provided security to concerts and generally kept the peace without bringing in the law.

item.title: Vellum, a downtown Ann Arbor restaurant, has closed
item.description: Vellum closed in January 2015. The Ann Arbor News story tells the part of the story of an innovative kitchen that was "like a laboratory", and a subsequent format change to a more mainstream menu. The restaurant had a two year run. What's missing from the narrative is the prompt from the county health department that forced the change. Vellum's menu at the outset used the "sous vide" cooking technique to produce its most innovative dishes.

item.title: Ann Arbor City Council highlights for 5 January 2015, a preview
item.description: Ann Arbor City Council is meeting tonight, 5 January 2015, at 7:00 p.m. the Washtenaw County Administration Building. Here are some highlights from the agenda. Three public hearings are on the docket. The public will get a chance to weigh in on a proposed amendment to the chicken-keeping ordinance and two hearings on downtown zoning. The chicken-keeping ordinance (Section 107) would be amended to allow people to keep 6 chickens instead of the current 4, and to allow people to keep chickens without getting the mandatory consent of the neighbors.

item.title: Olivetti Programma 101
item.description: The first computer that I ever had all to myself was the Olivetti Programma 101. This was a 1965-era Italian machine that was just a little more than a programmable calculator. It used flexible magnetic cards for program storage, discrete logic for all of its computing functions, delay line memory (240 bytes), and it all sat in a 65 pound package. Output was on a humming little printer built into the machine.

item.title: Twitter mobile application logout problems on December 28, 2014
item.description: If your mobile device got logged out of Twitter and you can't log back in, you're not alone. No report yet from status.twitter.com acknowledging the problem. Suggestions: a good book, or maybe Plurk.

item.title: What we don't know about AirAsia Flight 8501
item.description: As of this writing (2 am Sunday December 28 2014 in Ann Arbor MI) there is no word on the fate of the lost airliner Indonesia AirAsia Flight 8501 which went missing on a flight from Surabaya, Indonesia, to Singapore. Trying to find reliable information about an event in progress half way around the world is always a challenge. Twitter and Facebook are good at moving information quickly around the globe, but they send sense and nonsense in equal parts, and it's easy to read things that are speculation or even outright falsehoods.

item.title: Worst restaurants (and best restaurants) in November 2014 Washtenaw County health inspections
item.description: Every month I get an email with a spreadsheet of restaurant inspection reports from Washtenaw County. Here's a summary of the worst (and best) of the restaurants inspected in November 2014. There are three types of problems reported by county health. To simplify reporting I score them proportionately to see which locations go to the top of the list. 6 locations had no problems at all: DOG DAYS III 2515 JACKSON ANN ARBOR DOMINICK'S 812 MONROE ANN ARBOR HOTEL HICKMAN WILD WEST ADVENTURES STFU 2400 HICKMAN RD ANN ARBOR JIMMY JOHN'S GOURMET SANDWICHES 342 S.

item.title: Begger's funnel plot: a marker for irregularities in scientific publication
item.description: From Scientific American, [For Sale: “Your Name Here” in a Prestigious Science Journal] (http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/for-sale-your-name-here-in-a-prestigious-science-journal/) “Beggers funnel plot” is particularly revealing. There is no such thing as a Beggers funnel plot. "It doesn't exist. That's the point," says Guillaume Filion, a biologist at the Center for Genomic Regulation in Barcelona, Spain (pdf). A statistician named Colin Begg and another statistician named Matthias Egger each invented tests and tools to look for biases that creep into meta-analyses.

item.title: Listening to Radio Havana Cuba via shortwave
item.description: Radio Havana Cuba was one of my cold war era shortwave radio presets. I don't have a working shortwave radio of my own any more, and the miracle of the Internet means that you can now tune in broadcasts directly from the broadcaster without the inconvenience of shortwave tuning. The best way really to listen to a station like R Havana Cuba is via shortwave. Here are a couple of ways that you can do that.

item.title: Dr. Dobb's Journal shuffles off this mortal coil
item.description: Dr. Dobb's Journal is closing down, with its last issue appearing at the end of 2014. They tell their story in a final report. The key insight into the demise of this 38 year old publication is that this was their best year for online web traffic, yet their revenues were heading straight down. Four years ago, when I came to Dr. Dobb's, we had healthy profits and revenue, almost all of it from advertising.

item.title: Some notes on Echolink and websdr
item.description: Echolink is a system that lets amateur radio operators transmit from their computer, through a relay at a suitable Echolink server. You have to be a licensed ham to get on the network, and typically there's a two-way repeater set up to some radio station so that you can hear what's being said on RF and vice versa. websdr is a system that lets anyone listen to a slice of radio spectrum.

item.title: Obituary: John Gall, 1925-2014
item.description: Gall, John C. 9/18/1925 - 12/15/2014 Walker, MN John C. Gall, Jr., beloved husband, father, pediatrician, scholar and author, passed away with his wife by his side Dec. 15, 2014, in Walker, MN, from natural causes. He was 89. John was born on September 18, 1925 in Washington, D.C. and grew up near Upperville, VA. In 1945 he was drafted into the Army Air Corps and sent to Germany, where he served as a medic in the Allied army of occupation.

item.title: I'm taking a break from Twitter
item.description: Nothing personal, but it's time to take a break from Twitter. I tried to do this back in 2008 when it was still possible to have a reasonable conversation on a blog about whether you were or weren't going to participate in a new social media experiment. Nowadays Twitter is big business, and I don't feel like I have to justify myself to my friends for why I think it's time to take a rest from 24x7 news and celebrity updates.

item.title: Listening to the characteristic hum of the house with iSpectrum
item.description: This is what our house sounds like when the furnace fan is running - a steady 240 hz hum with harmonics at 120 hz and about 360 hz. The graph is from iSpectrum, an easy to set up audio spectrum analyzer from Dog Park Software.

item.title: Establishing a routine for processing inbound communications
item.description: I used Google Inbox for a little while, but gave up on it. It turns out that the routine I have with Google's Gmail for handling inbound correspondence is pretty good, and Inbox was too different from Gmail to make it worthwhile to do an easy transition. I don't know if my workflow for handling message traffic is perfect, but it seems to be pretty good. Email comes in, I read it, and anything that deserves further attention but can't be handled right away is starred.

item.title: No fly zone over Ferguson affects airport traffic at Lambert-St Louis Airport
item.description:
November 25, 2014, midnight. FAA has issued TFR affecting inbound flights. Airport is still open. Does not impact departures. — Lambert-STL Airport (@flystl) November 25, 2014 FAA TFR, NOTAM : 4/0271 Location : FERGUSON, MO, Tuesday, November 25, 2014 UTC. Not for navigation.
Flightstats shows that traffic is being diverted from the airport.
The FAA has issued a TFR over #Ferguson. But unlike last time, commercial flights are diverting away from @flystl.

item.title: Github-based kanban boards: Zenhub, Waffle, Huboard, Blossom et al
item.description: A kanban board is simply a two-dimensional view of a series of work queues. By moving a piece of work from one column to another, you update its status. This gives you a quick way to visualize your current priorities, as well as making it very clear when one or more of your queues are too full. I've been using Github issues as a personal issue tracker for a while, using its milestones feature to track categories.

item.title: Kinder Morgan gas pipeline maps
item.description:
Kinder Morgan runs a number of pipelines that carry natural gas through the United States. Detailed maps are available that show the current status for these pipelines.
This map is from the Tennessee Gas Pipeline which carries gas from the Gulf Coast to the Northeast US. The map is accompanied by a series of operational data and alerts that tell gas shippers what to expect, provide gas consumption forecasts based on the weather, and alerts users of the pipeline of exceptional events in the case of equipment failure.

item.title: Non-traditional maps to monitor severe weather
item.description: When ordinary weather maps don't tell you what the worst of the weather is like out there, I turn to these sources for information. Twitter, especially. A search this morning for "ann arbor ice" gave plenty of illustrations why it was not suitable to be out walking around. Streets and highways were bad, and a Delta flight slid off the runway at DTW. For Michigan weather follow the #miwx hashtag.

item.title: How does this system even work?
item.description: Some questions to ask while you're trying to sort this out. Draw a diagram of the entire system, from one end to the other. Label the parts. Identify especially the parts that "just work", because undoubtably there are unexpected cases that won't work just when you need them to work. Identify the message flows through the system. Where do signals get generated, where do they get retransmitted, where do they get changed and when does a human interpret them?

item.title: Wake up, get a cup of coffee, start typing
item.description: Wake up, get a cup of coffee, start typing. That's a pretty typical pattern for me these days, and I'm trying to make sense of whether it's a good one. The hardest part of making a morning typing routine work is to try to figure out what indeed it is that you are focusing on in those early caffeinated hours. There are lots of competitors for the morning attention, including yesterday's inbox, the overnight news, and the steady tick of Twitter and Facebook.

item.title: Tonight's #wjchat is about social media for long-term editorial projects
item.description: wjchat is a weekly Wednesday night chat session on Twitter. "wj" in this case is short for "web journalism". Tonight's session is on using social media for long term editorial projects. The longest long-term editorial project I'm working on that's relevant to this is Arborwiki, which is now part of the Localwiki project. It's a local encyclopedia of the Ann Arbor area, and as such it's a very useful spot to accumulate the back story for any story that you want to tell.

item.title: When I don't write it down to share with the world I don't learn it
item.description: I'm working on a project that will remain nameless. The sponsor of the project asked me not to write about it, and I agreed. I'm spending a lot of time communicating about the project, but those communications are all private. It's intensely frustrating. I learn best by writing about what I'm doing, in enough detail to capture some of the very small bits of what had happened while it was happening.

item.title: In retrospect, I should have walked out of the room.
item.description: Note to self: if you get asked to be part of a project, and then subsequently get asked to not talk about that project, renegotiate the terms of that effort promptly. Non-disclosure has wide ranging consequences, and that's especially true when you habitually learn about how something works by writing about it. In retrospect, I should have walked out of the room. That would have been brave and not foolish.

item.title: I envy people who can focus on exactly one thing for a long period of time
item.description: I envy people who can focus on exactly one thing for a long period of time. I'm not one of those people.

item.title: That bright idea of yours might cost you $25,000
item.description: A cautionary tale. What's the value of an idea? Consider that some ideas might have a negative value; indeed that most of them might. It may take you some substantial investment to test out your idea, to prove it, to build something minimal to show people that it was real. And then when you're ready with it there might be a net result that you finally have talked to enough people that you know that you need to scrap it and start over.

item.title: "Attila at The Gates of The Telephone Company", Richard Brautigan
item.description: They said that my telephone would be fixed by 6. They guaranteed it. (for Genghis)

item.title: Appeal of FOIA 14-315, redaction of names and email addresses
item.description: Update: The list below is of individuals and organizations that have requested the Absentee Voter file (AV file) for the most recent Ann Arbor election. The file includes the full names and addresses of individuals who have requested absentee ballots, as well as the status of the ballot in the current election (whether it has been voted yet or not). Political campaigns use this information to identify likely voters for campaign mailings.

item.title: Tor network takedown by the Nazgûl
item.description: I would liken Tor to putting on Sauron's ring. The wearer is invisible to ordinary beings, like Men, but highly visible to the Nazgûl. — Matthew Green (@matthew_d_green) October 24, 2014 Ars Technica writes (November 9, 2014) about the takedown of many sites on the Tor network. An excerpt: The theory posited by “the kid who started Doxbin“ to nachash was that the attack was an attempt to force connections to the site’s various .

item.title: 39th anniversary of the wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald on Nov 10, 2014
item.description: More about the song The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald on the 70s Pop blog. Death and destruction: why were we so obsessed with it in the 70s? So many gruesome, heart wrenching unhappy endings were fodder for pop songs and we gleefully bought the 45s. Well maybe not gleefully, maybe with a maudlin curiosity. This Gordon Lightfoot tune is a great example, a story song about the SS Edmund Fitzgerald sinking in 1975, killing everyone on board.

item.title: New cases of Ebola in sub-Saharan Africa; map from MMWR, September 28–October 18 2014
item.description:
Number of new cases of Ebola virus disease reported — West Africa, September 28–October 18
The figure above is a map of West Africa showing the number of new cases of Ebola reported in West Africa during September 28-October 18, 2014. Counts of Ebola were highest in the area around Monrovia and in the district of Bong, Liberia; the Freetown area and the northwest districts of Sierra Leone; and the district of Macenta, Guinea.

item.title: pruning some debris
item.description: The plan is to take about 5% of this weblog offline, not because there's anything embarrassing there, but simply because so much has built up over time that removing a slice of it will help incrementally with making the rest of it more valuable. Alas, Typepad is not optimized for surfing through 3000+ old bits of debris to figure out which of them are least interesting.

item.title: Obituary: Tom Fourner, WWII veteran, June 27, 1925 - November 7, 2014
item.description: Fournier, Thomas James 6/27/1925 - 11/7/2014 Tom Fournier died peacefully with family by his side on November 7, 2014. Tom was born on June 27, 1925 in Detroit, MI, to Christopher and Alice Fournier. He joined the Navy to fight in World War II and fought in the D-Day landing on Omaha Beach. After the war, Tom returned home to marry the love of his life, Joan, on June 1, 1946.

item.title: FOIA: A2 Fix It request, Issue ID: 1275000, Service Request ID: 272504 regarding traffic light at Pauline and Maple
item.description: To: Ann Arbor City Clerk Date: November 5, 2014 FOIA Please provide the following records: Records within the A2 Fix It / SeeClickFix system regarding Issue ID 127500, Service Request ID 272504, reported on September 8, 2014. Records within the city's Cityworks system related to this same service request. Any electronic mail communications associated with this service request not captured within A2 Fix It or Cityworks. Maintenance and service records for the traffic signal and associated systems at the corner of Pauline and Maple, specifically those related to the maintenance of, placement of, and plans for repair of the vehicle sensors at this location, believed to be records held by the Signs and Signals unit and associated with this issue.

item.title: Power outage map outage at Emera and Central Maine Power (Maine electrical utilities)
item.description:
November 2, 2014, 5:04 p.m. EST (Ann Arbor, MI): The state of Maine is being hit by winter storms, with more than 1 inch an hour falling across parts of the state. This has led to widespread power outages, as well as outages of the power outage maps provided by Emera and by Central Maine Power, two utility companies that serve the state.
Emera's live outage map is throwing an error at this time.

item.title: Art at U Hospital: Charting the Wolverine, a map collage by Elaine S Wilson
item.description: CHARTING THE WOLVERINE: MAP COLLAGE Elaine S. Wilson Elaine S. Wilson chronicles the experience of riding Amtrak’s train from Ann Arbor to Chicago by combining maps, aerial drawings and watercolor images. The prints are the result of over five years of research in map collections at the University of Michigan, Library of Congress and Yale University, as well as countless trips along the tracks to find sites identified from the windows of the train at which to set up her easel.

item.title: Chickpea, Potato and Tomato Stew: six recipes to mix and match from
item.description: Haven't cooked any of these yet, but there's some recipes to work through: Ricki Heller: Chickpea, Potato and Tomato Stew. Uses tahini to enrich the sauce. Fit Pregnancy: Chickpea, Potato and Tomato Stew with Chard . With chard, paprika, parsley. The First Mess: moroccan-style vegetable + chickpea stew . Sweet potatoes instead of potatoes, and a cinnamon+coriander+cumin spice. The Picky Eater: Indian Chickpea and Potato Stew. Curry is the flavor here, and cilantro replaces parsley.

item.title: Where do you write something that's longer than a tweet, but shorter than an essay?
item.description: Where do you write something that's longer than a tweet, but shorter than an essay? There's a space on the net for things that you put together that don't fit into a tweet, but that also don't really require a whole long essay. I've been writing these in my blog for years, and so I have a bit of infrastructure put together for organizing, collecting, and finding them again. A lot of people who are on Twitter don't have a blog, though, and so their fragments stay fragmentary or get lost in the mists of Twitter time.

item.title: Applesauce recipe
item.description: APPLESAUCE At farmer's market, ask the farmer for a half a peck or a peck of "mixed seconds for sauce". Use whatever apples they give you. In November 2014 I paid $7 for a peck of mixed seconds at the Ann Arbor Farmers Market. Quarter and core many apples; do not peel. Cover bottom of pot with water, put in the apples, half (or a whole) orange (pref. organic, with seeds removed), one (or two) cinnamon sticks.

item.title: beholden to the search engine
item.description: Some enormous fraction of the traffic to this web site appears because of search, specifically Google search. What if Google gets tired of reading my posts and recommending them to others?

item.title: Run away and join the Circus, for just one night. Nov 7, 2014 fundraiser for FLY Art Center
item.description: On Friday, Nov. 7, 2014, FLY Art Center's annual Circus fundraiser will create a circus, with a menagerie of carnival games and exotic performers in the Bona Sera underground space, 200 W. Michigan Ave., Ypsilanti, MI. Music and mingling, cash bar and circus food as well as Bona Sera's inventive and eclectic menu times. 6:30 to 10 pm. Cost: Donation of at least 25 cents. While the adults play at the Circus, children are invited to their own fun time at the Circus Side Show!

item.title: Snowshoe race bridge
pumpkin carving 2014
Mac OS 10.9.5 audio problems on MacBook Air
item.description: Symptoms include no audio inputs when a headset is plugged in, but the built-in mic works fine when the headset is not plugged in. sudo killall coreaudiod is one suggested fix. This superuser.com article tells you how to reload Mac audio drivers without rebooting. Thanks to Mohan Kartha for helping sort this out; still not convinced I can adequately fix it with these tools, or even that I have diagnosed the issue.

item.title: from a2b3 this week at Ayse's Courtyard Cafe
item.description: he’s ed @vielmetti. he organizes lunch. pic.twitter.com/wUAWmeGgcX — peter honeyman (@peterhoneyman) October 23, 2014

item.title: DTW -> LAX, DL 1706
item.description: Flight leaves at 835a ET.

item.title: The news: URL scheme
item.description: The simplest version of the news: URL scheme is just news:newsgroup. The 1998 draft of the description is here: https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-gilman-news-url-01 .

item.title: recipe: tortilla casserole
item.description: This comes out kind of like a lasagna and is designed the same way: lots of layers. Ingredients: one package tortillas (whole wheat, corn, or flour) one can tomatoes with chiles one can black beans 1/2 jar corn relish one package shredded cheese assemble in layers, roughly as so: tortillas tomatoes with chiles tortillas beans cheese tortillas relish cheese Bake in a 350 degree oven; I left it in for about an hour, until the top was nicely browned and not singed.

item.title: My Beautiful Hook-Nosed Beauty Queen Strut Wave - poetry by Jeff Kass
item.description: Dzanc Books is proud to announce the release of My Beautiful Hook-Nosed Beauty Queen Strut Wave, the debut full-length poetry collection from longtime Ann Arbor educator Jeff Kass. In addition to being an English teacher at Pioneer High School and the Literary Arts Director at The Neutral Zone, Kass is the author of the short story collection Knuckleheads, which won Independent Publishers Gold Medal for Best Short Fiction Collection of 2011.

item.title: tilde club, day 4: Usenet is back
item.description: tilde.club now has Usenet news, of the very old fashioned sort where there is only a small handful of newsgroups and where people are still figuring out their newsreaders and news hosting systems and where there's no spam. Instructions are at ~emv/usenet, such as they are; looking to get enough people on board so that there's a reasonable next step of setting up a feed infrastructure of some kind eventually. The current set of directions are rather plain, but it will get more fancy, just fancy enough to bootstrap but not much more.

item.title: Solar panel + batteries available for checkout at Ann Arbor District Library
item.description: I checked out a 27 watt solar panel with a very beefy battery from the Ann Arbor District Library. The battery also charges via a wall wart, and provides either 5V USB power or switchable 10V-19V DC. I've been thinking about getting a solar panel, and my conclusion is that 27 watts is overkill for my normal use case which is powering my phone. The battery was awesome, but again overkill - too heavy to be an everyday carry.

item.title: Lovely things written by others
item.description: ~nsb can see colors for the first time. "After 57 years on this planet, I suddenly like art museums." ~ford writes about his friend Tom, who died last week. "It was good to have known him." You can't flee Mercury in retrograde. (Lyrics by the Reverse Engineers). "our mission is to promote the experience of multi-user computing in an unstable and confusing environment." tilde.farm "Ello's for those who don't remember. This is the place for people who do.

item.title: tilde club, day 2: re-installing Usenet News on my Mac, and wishing for a tilde.* feed
item.description: The next major ancient Internet subsystem I'd like to get back is Usenet News. tin, trn, rn etc I all have a lot of muscle memory for, and by running netnews inside a closed network of other relatively trusted sites you have some hope of scaling the whole thing without needing to bust out into the swamp of the wild, wild Internet of netnews. There's tin, ready to be compiled when you are.

item.title: People I saw or met in Chicago
item.description: Just a list, so I can't forget who I saw on a very good trip to Chicago last week. Megabus. Cheap and cheerful transportation, very convenient to where I was going, good drivers both ways. The return trip bus was kind of old (e.g. the power outlets didn't work) but the driver was fantastic. HI-Chicago a hostel in the loop. Cheap and cheerful lodging, very convenient. Eric Sinclair and Anne Zender.

item.title: tilde.club notes, day 1: learning new stuff about the unix shell
item.description: Fun with source code control, so you don't lose any text. git and especially github is your friend. Fun with server-side includes, learning about the Meta refresh hack, and the XBitHack. I'm using screen to manage multiple shells on the same terminal. it seems to work nicely under mosh. In the process of doing so I managed to strand a bunch of mosh shells, which I'm going to clean up.

item.title: There's a reason I embraced blogging tools as soon as I found them
item.description: I'm playing on tilde.club/~emv. It's interesting and fun to try to write a weblog when you don't have any content management system other than the Unix shell, but at some point quickly you end up moving a file on top of another file and wiping out a bunch of work, and then it gets less fun. What I think I want to do there is write in Markdown, but somehow assemble bits of Markdown into what ends up looking like an old fashioned blog, with a sidebar that's interesting and ever-changing and a main blog part that's one post per day.

item.title: A test of Ridescout for Ann Arbor multi-modal transit use
item.description: RideScout is an app that provides info about a whole range of transit options, including taxi, car share, bus, parking, and more. They have support for Ann Arbor as a city, so I tried it while riding AAATA (The Ride). http://www.ridescoutapp.com/ It's the first independent app that I've seen that shows where every AAATA stop is, in a nice little app that works on your phone with a zippy little map that scrolls nicely.

item.title: "brew install lynx", and then Gopher lives on
item.description: Since we're reinventing the Olde Web with systems like tilde.club, here's a screen shot of the current state of Gopher. "brew install lynx" gets a Lynx client on my Mac, and then you point lynx at gopher://gopher.floodgap.com and you're good to go. "ssh new@sdf.org" and you can set yourself up a shell account with a gopher client installed and gopher server space available.

item.title: Working on traffic safety in Chicago
item.description:
noting along the way the Chicago Crash Browser, ChicagoCrashes.org.
The Michigan Traffic Crash Facts site is very competent as well, perhaps better than this Chicago site in some ways. This image shows bicycle crashes in Washtenaw County, 2013.

item.title: Working at 1871 in Chicago
item.description: 1871 is an enormous coworking and business incubator space on the 12th floor of the Merchandise Mart in Chicago. I'm spending the afternoon of October 7, 2014 there, as a guest of Christopher Whitaker from Code for America.

item.title: Staying at Hosteling International Chicago (HI-Chicago)
item.description: I'm completely happy with my choice of HI-Chicago as a place to stay. It's inexpensive, clean, well run, the staff is friendly, and there's lots of community space in the building to get things done in outside of your room. I stayed here for the eChicago conference in an 8-person room; this time I upgraded to the 4-person room. Two nights stay is less than $100, which is hard to beat.

item.title: Chicago postcards at the Chicago Architecture Foundation
item.description: Some very nice postcards indeed from their postcard rack, at about $1 a piece. I'm going to study them closely and them mail them off!

item.title: Marquette Cemetery Locator App video for Code Michigan 2014
using "jq" for command line web applications for civic data
item.description: One of the tools that I rediscovered and have been really happy for having done so is “jq”, a command line tool that bills itself as “awk for json”. I’ve been writing awk code since 1985, and some limited subset of it is something that I know really, really well. awk, however, is from the punchcard era, and as such it likes to deal with records that are all on one line each.

item.title: Notes on building the Marquette Park Cemetery finder app for Code Michigan
item.description: I'm working on a tool or a set of tools to assist people in finding grave sites in the Park Cemetery in Marquette, Michigan as a part of a project for Code Michigan. I'm working with a team that's based in the U.P. to do this, and we're collaborating over Google Hangouts. Code Michigan is a hackathon, so this project timeline is compressed to a single weekend. The team is Edward Vielmetti, Jim Argeropoulos, Chris Marr, and Lynn Czarnecki Makela.

item.title: Some notes on open data for
item.description: Throwing out some notes here for a panel I'm on at the #micities conference at the Michigan Union today October 4, 2014. The questions are around open data, considered as data published by a government agency that has a well defined data format (CSV, Excel, JSON, XML documented API, etc) well defined access path via Internet (HTTP, FTP, API) well defined terms of use and reuse Census data is perhaps the most openly open of open data.

item.title: I'm heading to Chicago. I'll be near the Loop. Where should I buy postcards?
item.description: I found the Chicago Postcard Museum which is all online; pity that it's not in a real place or I'd visit. Where would you go in the Loop to get good and interesting cards? I'm not interested in spending lots of money per card, but I would like to have a nice variety to choose from.

item.title: the internet of things world hasn't condensed into a single system, and because of its origins it's unlikely to do so.
item.description: The internet of things is a multi-protocol internet, with lots of legacy protocols in use as well as homemade protocols over TCP/IP and also serial port stuff and funky radio uses. Oh, and HTTP too. Some of the things in the internet of things are very small and have very low cost network capacity, which rules out using a full stack HTTP implementation. Others are not quite as small, but still don't have enough oomph to take on an Internet's worth of traffic, so you might run HTTP but still keep the devices firewalled very carefully from the Internet.

item.title: Severe storms of October 2, 2014 hit the Dallas-Fort Worth area; Oncor power outage map shows the storm track
item.description:
The Dallas-Fort Worth area was hit by severe storms the evening of October 2, 2014. The Dallas Morning News live blog details the impact, with more than 250,000 people without power. This outage map from about 7:00 p.m. that evening shows the extent of the damage.
My power outage tracker page is a good early warning of problems with the power grid. By looking at what web pages people are clicking through on, I can see where the troubles are.

item.title: The Bee App, a multiplatform issue tracker client for Mac
item.description: I've been tracking my personal todo list on Github for nearly two years now. When I first wrote up the experience I had just been using the standard web client for the system; since then I've added Octodroid as an Android client. So far so good, I've closed more than 2300 issues since I started. Github's issues is a completely feature-filled issue management system, far and above overkill for a personal todo list, but useful and complete enough to manage routine tasking.

item.title: Fall 2014 colors from space (from MODIS on the Terra satellite)
item.description:
NASA's Terra satellite captured this image of the Great Lakes, with fall colors clearly visible in the UP.
Image Credit: Jeff Schmaltz at NASA GSFC. Caption by Mike Carlowicz A few days after autumn showed up on the calendar in the Northern Hemisphere, it showed up on the landscape of North America. The Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer MODIS on NASA’s Terra satellite captured this view of fall colors around the Great Lakes on Sept.

item.title: portmanteuxber
item.description: the practice of adding -tober to every possible word; cf. Rocktober .

item.title: Answers from CTN regarding City of Ann Arbor closed captioning
item.description: Answers to questions sent to Greg McDonald, CTN manager, regarding closed captioning at on City of Ann Arbor's Community Television Network. Why are you providing closed captioning? The Commission on Disability Issues made a request to add captions to their meetings to increase meeting accessibility. Who is providing the closed captioning for CTN? ScreenLine, L.L.C. How much is the size of the contract, and for how long does it run?

item.title: Accumulating editorial debt and dealing with out-of-date text
item.description: Editorial debt accumulates when the passage of time makes a document less true, to the point where the written word has to be edited to keep it up to date or scrapped because the work is uselessly outdated. For fast-moving stories, the first edit will be wrong in many ways. There will be missing facts, incomplete images, and gaps in the narrative. This is short term editorial debt, which can be addressed once the immediate crisis has played itself out.

item.title: Do you still write 750 words a day?
item.description: I'm sure that I write way more than that in aggregate, but I've not been keeping up with what was once a habit I attempted: to write a 750 word essay every day. I know that it's possible to sit down with a single cup of coffee and a single idea and no distractions and crank out 500 words at a sitting. It helps if the coffee doesn't spill, and if your todo list is in check, and if you have a full sized keyboard and not a tiny phone.

item.title: A design for heat maps of parking system congestion
item.description: The unit of analysis is the parking structure. It has a capacity c, and a usage u(t) for any time t observed. If u/c > 0.8 the structure is congested; at u/c > 0.9 the structure is full. That reduces the time series of usage for a given structure into one of three values (green, yellow, red). Some public policy goal wants to keep the structures congested (to maximize revenues) but not full (to minimize complaints).

item.title: September 30, 2014 University of Michigan campus football protest
item.description: "This is so much better than a home game" -protestor — mgoblog (@mgoblog) September 30, 2014

item.title: Congestion map for US-23 north of Ann Arbor
item.description: This map, from an MDOT study of US-23 traffic congestion mitigation alternatives, is a very nice view of just how busy and how slow US-23 north of Ann Arbor is on a typical weekday. This image was pulled from the AAATA board packet for September 25, 2014, as published as a2docs 386. Other agencies looking to make a case for capacity improvements can refer to this clear graphic as a way of describing just exactly what's going on and when and where.

item.title: Michigan Green Burial Conference, October 11, 2014
